1 Overview

1.1. Features

Backbase Portal offers a flexible way to manage web portals. Its architecture is based on a rich presentation layer and a loosely coupled Web-Oriented Architecture, and combines content and interaction in one solution. This is most evident with widgets, independent web applications that form the portal building blocks.

With Backbase Portal, end-users can personalize the online environments, the information and the applications they need. They can also add content, adjust visualisation preferences, and rearrange layouts.

The following figure shows the main modules of Backbase Portal:

Backbase Portal Client.  Backbase Portal Client shows the portal and enables interaction with the widgets. It communicates with Backbase Portal Foundation on the background to store the changes the end-user makes to the portal.

Backbase Portal Foundation.  Backbase Portal Foundation is the main engine that receives requests from clients, retrieves objects from the data store, sends responses back to the client and stores changes in the data store. It can serve multiple portal instances. For more information, see Portal.

Mashup Services.  Mashup Services delivers remote content to Backbase Portal widgets. For more information, see Mashup Services.

Content Services.  Content Services, an optional module, delivers local and remote content to Backbase Portal widgets. For more information, see Content Services.

1.1 Features

Backbase Portal Foundation

  • Multi-tenancy—Backbase Portal Foundation is capable of hosting multiple portals.

  • Data Storage—a single data store stores all portal instances (and their personalization data), Access Control List mappings, and (optionally) user credentials. This combination provides the foundation for a robust and flexible authorization and authentication mechanism.

  • Personalization—changes made by end-users to their personal Backbase Portal space are persisted from one application session to the next. The storage of personalizations is based on storing only the changes made to the original object. This method makes the data store very efficient.

  • Authentication—the use of Spring Security allows custom integration with a variety of authentication services. Backbase Portal relies on a single identity store to serve all portal instances, and can be configured to use either an external identity store or one that resides in the Backbase Portal data store. For more information, see Authentication and Authorization.

  • Authorization—support for both role-based and resource-based authorization delivers a robust and flexible access control mechanism. In both cases, authorization is governed by the combination of the authenticated end-user, permissions (as defined by the groups to which an end-user belongs), and the Backbase Portal object the end-user is trying to access. For more information, see Authentication and Authorization.

  • Persistence—uses Hibernate to persist objects, users, groups and preferences to several supported databases.

  • Portal and Page Management—a REST interface is available for managing Backbase Portal Foundation and and the portal instances it hosts. For more information, please refer to the REST API.

  • Widget Compatibility—Backbase Portal supports multiple widget formats, including Backbase Portal 4 gadgets.

  • Widget Library—out-of-the-box widgets are available for common end-user tasks, including a login page.

Content Services

  • Content Aggregation—data imported from remote content sources is stored in the Content Services content repository.

  • Installation—Content Services is delivered as a web application (WAR file) that can be deployed to one or more J2EE application servers.

  • Integration—CMIS (Content Management Interoperability Services) and WebDAV interfaces for working with content.

  • Administration—JMX (Java Management Extensions) interface for managing and monitoring the delivery service.

  • Scalability—support for clustering means that Content Services instances can be configured for a variety of backend technologies, including enterprise-level databases and JCR (Java Content Repository).

  • Performance—support for clustering means that Content Services instances can be configured for optimal delivery.

  • Failover—support for clustering means that requests can be routed to different Content Services instances if one instance is unavailable.

  • Importers—an optional Content Services component for importing external feeds.

  • Schedulers—for automated import of content.

  • Persistence—uses Hibernate to persist content to several supported databases.

Mashup Services

  • Proxy Service—proxying is needed to overcome the same-origin security policy that modern browsers apply to AJAX calls. To request resources (such as an XML file or application) from other intranet or Internet domains, Proxy Services proxies the request to the remote resource.

  • Transformation Service—provides filters and transformers that act on the request/response workflow.

  • Caching Service—improves performance by writing requested resources to cache. The default caching mechanism is implemented using Ehcache.

2.1 Package Contents

The installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.2.1.2.zip) includes the following:

  • Web and Java applications

    • portal-dev-5.2.1.2.war — Backbase Portal Foundation

    • contentservices-webapp-5.2.1.0.war — Content Services

    • mashup-web-5.2.1.0.war — Mashup Services stand-alone application

    • orchestrator-5.2.1.0.war — Orchestrator

    Note

    If you want to develop Backbase Portal, it is recommended to set up a portal project instead of installing one of the delivered WAR files directly, see Development Setup.

  • Documentation

    • Product documentation of Backbase Portal

  • Configuration

    • Database scripts

Top

2.2 Backbase Portal Foundation

You can find the Backbase Portal Foundation WAR file in the installation package.

Note

If you want to develop Backbase Portal, it is recommended to set up a portal project instead of installing one of the delivered WAR files directly, see Development Setup.

If you are working with a portal project, you can package it into a WAR file, see Package the Project.

This topic describes how to install a Backbase Portal Foundation WAR file (whether from the installation package or created from a portal project).

Installation Prerequisites

The server that will host the portal needs to meet the following requirements:

  • A supported operating system, see Operating Systems.

  • An application server, see Application Servers.

  • A database, see Databases.

  • Java Developer Kit, see JDK.

  • Content Services (optional), see Content Services.

Installation Procedure

  1. Database setup

    Setup a supported database. See Databases.

  2. Set log folder

    Create a folder for logging, e.g. log in the installation folder of the application server. Run your application server with the -DPORTALSERVER_LOG_FOLDER=log_folder_path parameter, or add it to the JAVA_OPTS environment variable. Let log_folder_path point to the folder path, e.g. C:\Apache Tomcat\log.

  3. Proxy configuration

    The modules of Backbase Portal use proxy configurations to be aware of each other URLs. For more information, see Proxy Configuration.

  4. Deploy on application server

    Deploy the WAR file on a supported application server. See Application Servers.

  5. Test installation

    Point your browser to the Backbase Portal Foundation URL:

    http://host:port/applicationcontext

    The URL consists of the following parts:

    Table 2.1. Backbase Portal Foundation URL Parts

    URL Part

    Default

    Description

    host

    localhost

    The host name of the server that hosts Backbase Portal Foundation.

    port

    Jetty: 7777

    Apache Tomcat: 8080

    WebSphere: 9080

    JBoss: 8080

    When running the portal project, it uses an (embedded) Jetty server. You can set the port in the application server settings.

    applicationcontext

    portalserver

    This value usually reflects the name of the deployed WAR file.


    If the installation was successful, a welcome message should appear on the screen.

2.2.1 Databases

This section explains how to setup a database for Backbase Portal Foundation.

Important

It is important that all components used in the Backbase Portal environment are configured to support UTF-8 character encoding.

MySQL

  1. Open configuration file

    In Microsoft Windows, open or create the my.ini configuration file in the installation folder of MySQL. In Unix, open the /etc/mysql/my.cnf file. You can also create a database-specific configuration file.

  2. Set InnoDB storage engine

    Add the following to the [mysqld] section of the MySQL configuration file:

    default-storage-engine = innodb

  3. Set transaction isolation level

    Add the following to the [mysqld] section of the MySQL configuration file:

    transaction-isolation = READ-COMMITTED

  4. Disable identifier case sensitivity (Unix only)

    Add the following to the [mysqld] section of the MySQL configuration file:

    lower_case_table_names=2

  5. Set UTF-8 support

    Add the following to the [mysqld] section of the MySQL configuration file:

    init_connect='SET collation_connection = utf8_general_ci'
init_connect='SET NAMES utf8'
character-set-server=utf8
collation-server=utf8_general_ci
skip-character-set-client-handshake

    Add the following to the [mysql] section of the MySQL configuration file, or replace the property value if it is already defined:

    default-character-set=utf8

  6. Restart MySQL

Follow these steps using MySQL Workbench or another MySQL tool:

  1. Create schema

    Make sure the MySQL is running and log in as root.

    Create a database, a user, and grant the user privileges on the database as shown below:

    • Create a database:

      CREATE SCHEMA database;

    • Select the schema:

      USE database;

    • Create a user, assign it a password, and give it rights on the schema created in the previous step:

      CREATE USER 'bb_user'@'localhost' IDENTIFIED BY 'password';
GRANT ALL PRIVILEGES on bb_portal.* to 'bb_user'@'localhost';
FLUSH PRIVILEGES;

  2. Populate the database

    The scripts to populate the database are located in configuration/portalserver/scripts/mysql in your portal project and in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.2.1.2.zip).

    • Run the schema.ddl script to create the database objects, or copy the file contents and paste them to the MySQL command line.

    • Run the default-foundation-data-blank.sql script to populate the database with a minimal data set. To run the script from the command line, type the following:

      mysql -uroot -ppassword database_name < default-foundation-data-blank.sql

Note

If you need to drop all schemas and re-configure the database, run the drop_schema.sql script located in configuration/portalserver/scripts/mysql in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.2.1.2.zip).

Continue installing Backbase Portal Foundation.

Oracle

  1. Create user

    Make sure Oracle is running and log into the SQLPlus command line tool as administrator.

    Create a user, grant it privileges, and grant unlimited tablespace as shown below:

    CREATE USER username
PROFILE DEFAULT
IDENTIFIED BY password
DEFAULT TABLESPACE users
TEMPORARY TABLESPACE temp
ACCOUNT UNLOCK;

GRANT CREATE SESSION, CREATE TABLE, CREATE PROCEDURE,
CREATE SEQUENCE, CREATE VIEW, CREATE TRIGGER,
CREATE SYNONYM, CREATE MATERIALIZED VIEW,
QUERY REWRITE, CREATE ANY DIRECTORY, CREATE TYPE
TO username;

GRANT UNLIMITED TABLESPACE TO username;

  2. Populate the database

    Log in with the user you just created and run the scripts schema.ddl and default-foundation-data-blank.sql that will populate the database. These scripts are located in configuration/portalserver/scripts/oracle in your portal project and in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.2.1.2.zip).

    First, navigate to the directory that holds the scripts. Then, use the following commands:

    @schema.ddl
@default-foundation-data-blank.sql

Note

If you need to drop all schemas and re-configure the database, run the drop_schema.sql script located in configuration/portalserver/scripts/oracle in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.2.1.2.zip).

Continue installing Backbase Portal Foundation.

IBM DB2

  1. Create database

    Follow these steps using the IBM DB2 Configuration assistant and Control Center:

    • Create a database

      Right-click on All Databases, select Create Database..., and pick Standard. In the resulting screen give a database name, change the codeset to UTF-8 and click on Finish.

    • Create user

      Create a user account on the operating system.

    • Create schema

    • Grant rights on schema

      Give the user created in the previous step rights on the database. Add the schema created in the previous step to the user and grant all rights on that schema.

  2. Connect to the database

    Use the following command:

    db2 connect to [database] user [username] using [password]

    For example:

    db2 connect to portal5 user backbase using bb1234

  3. Populate the database

    Run the schema.ddl and default-foundation-data-blank.sql scripts to populate the database. These scripts are located in configuration/portalserver/scripts/db2 in your portal project and in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.2.1.2.zip).

    First, navigate to the directory that holds the scripts. Then, use the following commands:

    db2 -td; -vf schema.ddl
db2 -td@ -vf default-foundation-data-blank.sql

Note

If you need to drop all schemas and re-configure the database, run the drop_schema.sql script located in configuration/portalserver/scripts/db2 in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.2.1.2.zip).

Continue installing Backbase Portal Foundation.

Microsoft SQL Server

  1. Create database and user

    Follow these steps using Microsoft SQL Server Management Studio:

    1. Log in as system administrator

    2. Create database

    3. Set transaction isolation level

      Run the following commands on the database you just created:

      ALTER DATABASE database_name SET READ_COMMITTED_SNAPSHOT ON
ALTER DATABASE database_name SET ALLOW_SNAPSHOT_ISOLATION ON

    4. Create schema

    5. Create user

      In the login properties, set the created database and schema as default for this user. Make the user dbowner of the database.

  2. Populate the database

    The scripts to populate the database are located in configuration/portalserver/scripts/sqlserver2008 in your portal project and in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.2.1.2.zip).

    • Run the schema.ddl script to create the database objects.

    • Run the default-foundation-data-blank.sql script to populate the database with a minimal data set.

Note

If you need to drop all schemas and re-configure the database, run the drop_schema.sql script located in configuration/portalserver/scripts/sqlserver2008 in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.2.1.2.zip).

Continue installing Backbase Portal Foundation.

2.2.2 Application Servers

This section explains how to deploy Backbase Portal Foundation on specific application servers.

Important

It is important that all components used in the Backbase Portal environment are configured to support UTF-8 character encoding.

Apache Tomcat

  1. Apache Tomcat configuration

    The following steps describe how to setup Apache Tomcat for the JNDI data source on which Backbase Portal Foundation depends:

    1. Install a JDBC driver in the lib folder in the Apache Tomcat installation folder.

      The JDBC driver needs to be compatible with the following:

      • Database you are using

      • JDK you are using

      • JDBC API 4.0 specification

      • JDBC Type 4

      The following table shows a list of compatible drivers:

      Table 2.2. JDBC Driver

      Database

      JDBC Driver

      MySQL

      Connector/J

      Oracle

      Select a compatible driver for your database and JDK version: Oracle 11 JDBC Drivers

      IBM DB2

      Select a compatible driver for your database version: DB2 JDBC Drivers

      The downloaded archive will contain a JAR file for JDBC 4.0, e.g. db2jcc4.jar

      Microsoft SQL Server

      Microsoft SQL Server JDBC Driver


    2. This step only applies to Apache Tomcat 7. Find the <Context> definition in the conf/context.xml file in the Apache Tomcat installation folder. Replace <Context> with <Context useHttpOnly="false">.

    3. Add the following datasource configuration within the <Context> definition in the conf/context.xml file in the Apache Tomcat installation folder:

      <Resource name="jdbc/portalDS"
 auth="Container"
 type="javax.sql.DataSource"
 maxActive="4"
 maxIdle="2"
 username="my_username"
 password="my_password"
 maxWait="5000"
 driverClassName="jdbc_driver_class"
 url="database_url"/>

      Enter the following data in the database configuration:

      • Enter the username and password that have rights to the database for Backbase Portal. For more information, see Databases.

      • Enter the compatible JDBC driver class:

        Table 2.3. JDBC Driver

        Database

        JDBC Driver Class

        MySQL

        com.mysql.jdbc.Driver

        Oracle

        oracle.jdbc.driver.OracleDriver

        IBM DB2

        com.ibm.db2.jcc.DB2Driver

        Microsoft SQL Server

        com.microsoft.sqlserver.jdbc.SQLServerDriver

        H2 Database Engine

        org.h2.Driver


      • Enter the URL of the database. The default URL for the supported databases are as follows:

        Table 2.4. Database URL

        Database

        URL

        MySQL

        jdbc:mysql://localhost:3306/database

        Oracle XE

        jdbc:oracle:thin:@localhost:1521/XE

        Oracle

        jdbc:oracle:thin:@localhost:1521/database

        IBM DB2

        jdbc:db2://localhost:50000/database

        Microsoft SQL Server

        jdbc:jtds:sqlserver://localhost:1433/database

        H2 Database Engine

        jdbc:h2:file:path/to/database;MODE=MySQL;IGNORECASE=TRUE;MVCC=TRUE


        Enter the database name in the URL. For more information, see Databases.

        The database host and port can differ depending on your particular database settings.

        Important

        If you append the database URL with query parameters, make sure to use the & entity to avoid XML parsing errors.

    4. To enable UTF-8 support, open the conf/server.xml file located in the Apache Tomcat installation folder. Modify the Connector definition of the application port.

      For example, if Apache Tomcat uses port 8080, the <Connector> definition looks like the following:

      <Connector port="8080" protocol="HTTP/1.1"
    connectionTimeout="20000"
    URIEncoding="UTF-8"
    redirectPort="8443" />

  2. Set Java options

    Run your application server with the parameters -Xmx512m -XX:MaxPermSize=256m, or add it to the JAVA_OPTS environment variable. This increases the amount of memory that Java can use.

  3. Set Spring profile

    Run Apache Tomcat with the following parameter, or add it to the JAVA_OPTS environment variable:

    -Dspring.profiles.active=ps-database_server,ptc-[local|remote]

    1. Replace database_server with the database of Backbase Portal Foundation:

      Table 2.5. Database Parameters

      Database

      Parameter

      MySQL

      mysql

      Oracle

      oracle

      IBM DB2

      db2

      Microsoft SQL Server

      sqlserver

      H2 Database Engine

      h2

      If you do not specify the ps-database_server profile, Backbase Portal Foundation defaults to H2 Database Engine.


    2. Set [local|remote] to local if you want to use Mashup Services embedded in Backbase Portal Foundation. Set it to remote if you have installed Mashup Services stand-alone. If you do not specify the ptc-[local|remote] profile, Backbase Portal Foundation defaults to local.

      Note that if you set the profile to ptc-remote, the embedded instance of Mashup Services is disabled.

    For example, the parameter for MySQL and Mashup Services stand-alone is as follows:

    -Dspring.profiles.active=ps-mysql,ptc-remote

    Warning

    If Orchestrator runs on the same application server as Backbase Portal Foundation, spring.profiles.active should also include a profile for Orchestrator: orchestrator-database_server. For more information, see Orchestrator.

    Warning

    Either specify all profiles or none. If you only specify some of the profiles, these will be ignored and the defaults will be used instead.

  4. Deploy the WAR file

    Change the WAR file name to portalserver.war (to set the context root). Deploy the WAR file with the Tomcat Web Application Manager.

    Note

    If a URL redirection changes the application context root, use the this.config.resourceRoot and this.config.serverRoot parameters in the portal.js file to reset the resources and REST Interface contexts, respectively.

Continue installing Backbase Portal Foundation.

WebSphere

  1. Add XMI file to WEB-INF folder

    If you are not working with the Maven portal project, you need to address this step after deploying the WAR file.

    Save the following content as ibm-web-ext.xmi in src/main/webapp/WEB-INF in your portal project before packaging the project as a WAR file.

    <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<!-- This is a WebSphere specific configuration. Making sure that JSPs are compiled with 1.5. By default JSPs are compiled with 1.4 -->
<com.ibm.ejs.models.base.extensions.webappext:WebAppExtension xmlns:xmi="http://www.omg.org/XMI" xmlns:com.ibm.ejs.models.base.extensions.webappext="webappext.xmi" xmi:version="2.0" xmi:id="WebAppExtension_1">
    <webApp href="WEB-INF/web.xml#WebApp_1"/>
    <jspAttributes xmi:id="JSPAttribute_1" name="jdkSourceLevel" value="15"/>
    <jspAttributes xmi:id="JSPAttribute_2" name="useImplicitTagLibs" value="true"/>
</com.ibm.ejs.models.base.extensions.webappext:WebAppExtension>

  2. WebSphere configuration

    The following steps describe how to setup the application server for the JNDI data source on which Backbase Portal Foundation depends:

    1. Install a JDBC driver in the lib folder in the WebSphere installation folder.

      The JDBC driver needs to be compatible with the following:

      • Database you are using

      • JDK you are using

      • JDBC API 4.0 specification

      • JDBC Type 4

      The following table shows a list of compatible drivers:

      Table 2.6. JDBC Driver

      Database

      JDBC Driver

      MySQL

      Connector/J

      Oracle

      Select a compatible driver for your database and JDK version: Oracle 11 JDBC Drivers

      IBM DB2

      Select a compatible driver for your database version: DB2 JDBC Drivers

      The downloaded archive will contain a JAR file for JDBC 4.0, e.g. db2jcc4.jar

      Microsoft SQL Server

      Microsoft SQL Server JDBC Driver


    2. Set the JDBC driver in the WebSphere configuration.

      Open the integrated WebSphere console, and navigate to Resources > JDBC > JDBC Providers. Set the properties as follows:

      Table 2.7. JDBC Properties

      Property

      Value

      Scope

      cell

      Classpath

      full_path_of_database_JDBC_driver_class_files

      Implementation class

      Enter the compatible JDBC data source, see table below.


      Table 2.8. JDBC Data Source

      Database

      JDBC Data Source

      MySQL

      com.mysql.jdbc.jdbc2.optional.MysqlConnectionPoolDataSource

      Oracle

      oracle.jdbc.pool.OracleConnectionPoolDataSource

      IBM DB2

      If WebSphere runs on an IBM machine: com.ibm.db2.jdbc.app.UDBConnectionPoolDataSource

      If WebSphere runs on a Microsoft Windows or Unix machine: com.ibm.db2.jcc.DB2ConnectionPoolDataSource

      Microsoft SQL Server

      com.microsoft.sqlserver.jdbc.SQLServerConnectionPoolDataSource


    3. Create a new JC2 Authentication Alias:

      • In the integrated WebSphere console, navigate to Resources > JDBC > Data Sources.

      • Start the wizard to create a data source and click the create a new J2C authentication alias link.

      • For the JDBC connection, enter a username and password that provide access to the database.

    4. Create the data source:

      • In the integrated WebSphere console, navigate to Resources > JDBC > Data Sources.

      • Enter portalDS for both the data source name and the JNDI name.

      • Select the newly created JDBC connection username and password.

      • Select the newly created JDBC provider.

      • Leave the name of the data store helper class unchanged.

      • Deselect the Use this data source in container managed persistence (CMP) option.

      • Navigate to Resources > JDBC > Data Sources and select the portalDS data source.

      • Click the Custom Properties link and set the databaseName property to portalFoundation.

  3. Set Java options

    Run your application server with the parameters -Xmx512m -XX:MaxPermSize=256m, or add it to the JAVA_OPTS environment variable. This increases the amount of memory that Java can use.

  4. Set Spring profile

    Run WebSphere with the following parameter, or add it to the JAVA_OPTS environment variable:

    -Dspring.profiles.active=ps-database_server,ptc-[local|remote]

    1. Replace database_server with the database of Backbase Portal Foundation:

      Table 2.9. Database Parameters

      Database

      Parameter

      MySQL

      mysql

      Oracle

      oracle

      IBM DB2

      db2

      Microsoft SQL Server

      sqlserver

      H2 Database Engine

      h2

      If you do not specify the ps-database_server profile, Backbase Portal Foundation defaults to H2 Database Engine.


    2. Set [local|remote] to local if you want to use Mashup Services embedded in Backbase Portal Foundation. Set it to remote if you have installed Mashup Services stand-alone. If you do not specify the ptc-[local|remote] profile, Backbase Portal Foundation defaults to local.

      Note that if you set the profile to ptc-remote, the embedded instance of Mashup Services is disabled.

    For example, the parameter for MySQL and Mashup Services stand-alone is as follows:

    -Dspring.profiles.active=ps-mysql,ptc-remote

    Warning

    If Orchestrator runs on the same application server as Backbase Portal Foundation, spring.profiles.active should also include a profile for Orchestrator: orchestrator-database_server. For more information, see Orchestrator.

    Warning

    Either specify all profiles or none. If you only specify some of the profiles, these will be ignored and the defaults will be used instead.

  5. Deploy the WAR file

    Deploy the WAR file. If you are deploying on WebSphere 6.1 with Web Services Feature Pack, follow the additional steps for WebSphere 6.1 with Web Services Feature Pack. Set the context root to portalserver and map the web application portalDS data source to the application server portalDS data source.

    Note

    If a URL redirection changes the application context root, use the this.config.resourceRoot and this.config.serverRoot parameters in the portal.js file to reset the resources and REST Interface contexts, respectively.

Continue installing Backbase Portal Foundation.

JBoss

  1. Decompress the WAR file

    The following steps apply to the WAR file generated by Maven as well as the WAR files in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.2.1.2.zip). Decompress the relevant WAR file.

  2. Remove conflicting dependencies

    Remove xercesImpl-2.9.1.jar, stax-api-1.0.1.jar, stax-api-1.0-2.jar, and xml-apis-1.3.04.jar from the application dependencies located in the WEB-INF/lib folder in the unpacked WAR file.

  3. Web container configuration

    In the WEB-INF folder in the unpacked WAR file add a file named jboss-web.xml containing the following lines:

    <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" ?>
<jboss-web>
    <resource-ref>
        <res-ref-name>jdbc/portalDS</res-ref-name>
        <res-type>javax.sql.DataSource</res-type>
        <mapped-name>jdbc/portalDS</mapped-name>
        <res-auth>Container</res-auth>
        <jndi-name>java:/jdbc/portalDS</jndi-name>
    </resource-ref>
    <resource-env-ref>
        <resource-env-ref-name>portalserver/contentproxy/config</resource-env-ref-name>
        <jndi-name>portalserver/contentproxy/config</jndi-name>
    </resource-env-ref>
    <resource-env-ref>
        <resource-env-ref-name>portalserver/config</resource-env-ref-name>
        <jndi-name>portalserver/config</jndi-name>
    </resource-env-ref>
    <resource-env-ref>
        <resource-env-ref-name>portalmanager/ice-config</resource-env-ref-name>
        <jndi-name>portalmanager/ice-config</jndi-name>
    </resource-env-ref>
</jboss-web>

    Warning

    JBoss may throw a binding exception if the jboss-web.xml file in the WEB-INF folder in the unpacked WAR file contains carriage return characters. If this is the case, use this file instead, which has been tested to work.

  4. Install the JDBC driver

    Install a JDBC driver in the {JBOSS-HOME}/server/default/lib folder.

    Note

    Make sure the JDBC driver matches the JDK used by JBoss, i.e. JDK 5 or JDK 6. If you are running Oracle as database you will have to choose between the ojdbc5.jar and ojdbc6.jar drivers.

    The JDBC driver needs to be compatible with the following:

    • Database you are using

    • JDK you are using

    • JDBC API 4.0 specification

    • JDBC Type 4

    The following table shows a list of compatible drivers:

    Table 2.10. JDBC Driver

    Database

    JDBC Driver

    MySQL

    Connector/J

    Oracle

    Select a compatible driver for your database and JDK version: Oracle 11 JDBC Drivers

    IBM DB2

    Select a compatible driver for your database version: DB2 JDBC Drivers

2.3.1 Databases

This section explains how to setup a database for Content Services.

Important

It is important that all components used in the Backbase Portal environment are configured to support UTF-8 character encoding.

MySQL

  1. Edit configuration file

    Edit the my.cnf or my.ini configuration files located in the installation folder of MySQL. You might also want to create a database-specific configuration file.

    1. Set InnoDB storage engine

      Add the following to the [mysqld] section of the MySQL configuration file:

      default-storage-engine = innodb

    2. Set UTF-8 support

      Add the following to the [mysqld] section of the MySQL configuration file:

      init_connect='SET collation_connection = utf8_general_ci'
init_connect='SET NAMES utf8'
character-set-server=utf8
collation-server=utf8_general_ci
skip-character-set-client-handshake

      Add the following to the [mysql] section of the MySQL configuration file, or replace the property value if it is already defined:

      default-character-set=utf8

  2. Restart MySQL

Follow these steps using MySQL Workbench or another MySQL tool:

  1. Create schemas

    Create three schemas for configuration, content and resource, for example by typing the following:

    CREATE SCHEMA configuration;
CREATE SCHEMA content;
CREATE SCHEMA resource;

  2. Create users

    Create a user for each schema and grant it at least the following privileges: ALTER, ALTER ROUTINE, CREATE, CREATE ROUTINE, CREATE TEMPORARY TABLES, CREATE VIEW, DELETE, DROP, EXECUTE, INDEX, INSERT, SELECT and UPDATE:

    CREATE USER 'configuration'@'localhost' IDENTIFIED BY 'password';
GRANT ALTER, ALTER ROUTINE, CREATE, CREATE ROUTINE, CREATE TEMPORARY TABLES, CREATE VIEW, DELETE, DROP, EXECUTE, INDEX, INSERT, SELECT, UPDATE ON configuration.* TO 'configuration'@'localhost';

CREATE USER 'content'@'localhost' IDENTIFIED BY 'password';
GRANT ALTER, ALTER ROUTINE, CREATE, CREATE ROUTINE, CREATE TEMPORARY TABLES, CREATE VIEW, DELETE, DROP, EXECUTE, INDEX, INSERT, SELECT, UPDATE ON content.* TO 'content'@'localhost';

CREATE USER 'resource'@'localhost' IDENTIFIED BY 'password';
GRANT ALTER, ALTER ROUTINE, CREATE, CREATE ROUTINE, CREATE TEMPORARY TABLES, CREATE VIEW, DELETE, DROP, EXECUTE, INDEX, INSERT, SELECT, UPDATE ON resource.* TO 'resource'@'localhost';

  3. Select each schema and populate the database

    Select each of the three schemas and run the create-schema-bbcs.sql script to create the database objects.

    The script is located in the configuration/contentservices/scripts/mysql folder in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.2.1.2.zip).

    To run the script from the command line, type the following:

    mysql -uroot -ppassword database_name < create-schema-bbcs.sql

Note

If you need to drop all schemas and re-configure the database, run the drop-schema-bbcs.sql script located in configuration/contentservices/scripts/mysql in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.2.1.2.zip).

Continue installing Content Services.

Oracle

Please make sure that the Oracle database server is running. Follow these steps using the SQLPlus command line tool:

  1. Log in as system user

  2. Create users

    Create three user accounts respectively named bbdbconfiguration, bbdbcontent and bbdbresource. Map the user profiles to the desired default and temporary tablespaces, and add the desired quota settings.

    This should result in the following instructions:

    CREATE USER user_name
IDENTIFIED BY password
DEFAULT TABLESPACE tablespace_name
TEMPORARY TABLESPACE temp_tablespace_name
QUOTA quota_amount ON tablespace_name;

  3. Assign user rights

    Grant users the necessary rights to create tables, views and sequences:

    GRANT create session TO user_name;
GRANT create table TO user_name;
GRANT create view TO user_name;
GRANT create sequence TO user_name;

  4. Create schemas

    Create the schemas as system user:

    CREATE SCHEMA AUTHORIZATION user_name;

  5. Create the database tables

    Log in as each of the users created in Step 2 and run the create-schema-bbcs.sql script contained in the configuration/contentservices/scripts/oracle folder in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.2.1.2.zip). The script creates the necessary database tables.

Note

If you need to drop all schemas and re-configure the database, run the drop-schema-bbcs.sql script located in configuration/contentservices/scripts/oracle in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.2.1.2.zip).

Continue installing Content Services.

IBM DB2

Please make sure that the DB2 database server is running. Follow these steps using the IBM DB2 Control Center:

  1. Create operating system users

    DB2 users are mapped to users on the host operating system. Create three new operating system users named, respectively, bbdbconfiguration, bbdbcontent and bbdbresource.

  2. Log into IBM DB2 Control Center as system user

  3. Create new DB2 database

    Create a new database named BackbaseCS under the Databases node. Set the default bufferpool and table space page size to the maximum value allowed, e.g. 32K. In the Region/Locale setup, select the UTF-8 character set.

  4. Create database users

    Create three database users named, respectively, bbdbconfiguration, bbdbcontent and bbdbresource, and map them to the corresponding operating system users.

  5. Assign user authorities

    Grant users the necessary authorities: a minimum set is Connect, Create tables, Create packages, Create schemas implicitly, Access Load Utility and Connect to quiesced database.

  6. Create schemas

    Create three schemas named like the database users: bbdbconfiguration, bbdbcontent and bbdbresource. Add the corresponding user to each schema as Authorization name.

  7. Create database tables

    Log in as each of the users created in Step 4. From IBM DB2 Command Editor run the create-schema-bbcs.sql script contained in the configuration/contentservices/scripts/db2 folder in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.2.1.2.zip). The script creates the necessary database tables.

Note

If you need to drop all schemas and re-configure the database, run the drop-schema-bbcs.sql script located in configuration/contentservices/scripts/db2 in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.2.1.2.zip).

Continue installing Content Services.

Microsoft SQL Server

Follow these steps using the Microsoft SQL Server Management Studio:

  1. Log in as system administrator

  2. Create databases

    Create three databases respectively named configuration, content and resource.

  3. Set transaction isolation level

    Run the following commands on the databases you just created:

    ALTER DATABASE database_name SET READ_COMMITTED_SNAPSHOT ON
ALTER DATABASE database_name SET ALLOW_SNAPSHOT_ISOLATION ON

  4. Create users

    Create a user for each database and grant it all privileges on that database. For instance, create a user named configuration and grant it all privileges on the configuration database. Do the same for the two remaining databases.

  5. Select each schema and populate the database

    Select each of the three schemas and run the create-schema-bbcs.sql script to create the database objects.

    The script is located in the configuration/contentservices/scripts/sqlserver folder in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.2.1.2.zip).

Note

If you need to drop all schemas and re-configure the database, run the drop-schema-bbcs.sql script located in configuration/contentservices/scripts/sqlserver in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.2.1.2.zip).

Continue installing Content Services.

Known issues

Stricter servlet specifications on JBoss may cause Spring MVC exceptions when trying to display a page. 2.4.1 Databases

This section explains how to setup a database for Orchestrator.

Important

It is important that all components used in the Backbase Portal environment are configured to support UTF-8 character encoding.

MySQL

Follow these steps using MySQL Workbench or the MySQL command line:

  1. Create schema

    Make sure the MySQL is running and log in as root.

    Create a database, a user, and grant the user privileges on the database as shown below:

    • Create a database:

      CREATE SCHEMA database;

    • Select the schema:

      USE database;

    • Create a user, assign it a password, and give it rights on the schema created in the previous step:

      CREATE USER 'bb_user'@'localhost' IDENTIFIED BY 'password';
GRANT ALL PRIVILEGES on bb_portal.* to 'bb_user'@'localhost';
FLUSH PRIVILEGES;

  2. Populate the database

    Run the create_database.sql script located in configuration/orchestrator/scripts/mysql in your portal project and in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.2.1.2.zip). This script creates the necessary database tables. To run the script from the command line, type the following:

    mysql -uroot -ppassword database_name < create_database.sql

    Note

    If you need to drop all schemas and re-configure the database, run the drop_database.sql script located in configuration/orchestrator/scripts/mysql in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.2.1.2.zip).

Continue installing Orchestrator.

Oracle

  1. Create user

    Make sure Oracle is running and log into the SQLPlus command line tool as administrator.

    Create a user, grant it privileges, and grant unlimited tablespace as shown below:

    CREATE USER username
PROFILE DEFAULT
IDENTIFIED BY password
DEFAULT TABLESPACE users
TEMPORARY TABLESPACE temp
ACCOUNT UNLOCK;

GRANT CREATE SESSION, CREATE TABLE, CREATE PROCEDURE,
CREATE SEQUENCE, CREATE VIEW, CREATE TRIGGER,
CREATE SYNONYM, CREATE MATERIALIZED VIEW,
QUERY REWRITE, CREATE ANY DIRECTORY, CREATE TYPE
TO username;

GRANT UNLIMITED TABLESPACE TO username;

  2. Populate the database

    Log in with the user you just created and run the create_database.sql script contained in the configuration/orchestrator/scripts/oracle folder in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.2.1.2.zip). The script creates the necessary database tables.

Note

If you need to drop all schemas and re-configure the database, run the drop_database.sql script located in configuration/orchestrator/scripts/oracle in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.2.1.2.zip).

Continue installing Orchestrator.

IBM DB2

  1. Create database

    Follow these steps using the IBM DB2 Configuration assistant and Control Center:

    • Create a database

      Right-click on All Databases, select Create Database..., and pick Standard. In the resulting screen give a database name, change the codeset to UTF-8 and click on Finish.

    • Create user

      Create a user account on the operating system.

    • Create schema

    • Grant rights on schema

      Give the user created in the previous step rights on the database. Add the schema created in the previous step to the user and grant all rights on that schema.

  2. Connect to the database

    Use the following command:

    db2 connect to [database] user [username] using [password]

    For example:

    db2 connect to portal5 user backbase using bb1234

  3. Populate the database

    Log in with the user you just created and run the create_database.sql script contained in the configuration/orchestrator/scripts/db2 folder in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.2.1.2.zip). The script creates the necessary database tables.

    First, navigate to the directory that holds the scripts. Then, use the following commands:

    db2 -td@ -vf create_database.sql

Note

If you need to drop all schemas and re-configure the database, run the drop_database.sql script located in configuration/orchestrator/scripts/db2 in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.2.1.2.zip).

Continue installing Orchestrator.

  1. Create database and user

    Follow these steps using Microsoft SQL Server Management Studio:

    1. Log in as system administrator

    2. Create database

    3. Set transaction isolation level

ALTER DATABASE database_name SET ALLOW_SNAPSHOT_ISOLATION ON

    4. Create schema

Continue installing Orchestrator.

H2 Database Engine

  1. Download the the latest version of the H2 Database Engine and store it in your classpath, e.g. the lib folder of the application server.

  2. Run the create_database.sql script located in the configuration/orchestrator/scripts/h2 folder in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.2.1.2.zip) with the command below. Specify the location and file name to store the database in the url flag. The file name you specify will be appended with .h2.db.

    Set the user credentials you want in the user and password flags.

    java -cp path/to/h2/h2-latest.jar org.h2.tools.RunScript -url jdbc:h2:file:path/to/orchestrator_db -user sa -password sa -script path/to/zipfile/configuration/orchestrator/scripts/h2/create_database.sql

    For example, on Microsoft Windows and using Apache Tomcat 7 you could use the following command from the location of the create_database.sql file:

    java -cp "C:\Program Files\Apache\Tomcat 7.0\lib\h2-latest.jar" org.h2.tools.RunScript -url jdbc:h2:file:C:\.orchestrator\database -user sa -password sa -script create_database.sql

Note

If you need to drop all schemas and re-configure the database, delete the database file you just created and repeat the previous step.

    -Dspring.profiles.active=orchestrator-database_server

    Replace database_server with the database of Orchestrator:

2.5 Mashup Services

Mashup Services is a module that offers proxy capabilities to Backbase Portal. It comes embedded with Backbase Portal Foundation by default, but one can install it stand-alone on a separate environment.

Follow these instructions to install Mashup Services stand-alone.

Installation Prerequisites

Prior to installation, check that the following requirements are met:

  • A supported operating system, see Operating Systems.

  • An application server, see Application Servers.

  • Java Developer Kit, see JDK.

Installation Procedure

The following steps explain how to install Mashup Services on a stand-alone system:

  1. Proxy configuration

    The modules of Backbase Portal use proxy configurations to be aware of each other URLs. For more information, see Proxy Configuration.

  2. Set Spring profile

    Set the Backbase Portal Foundation Spring profile to ptc-remote. You can set this Spring profile in the start script of the application server that runs Backbase Portal Foundation or in the JAVA_OPTS environment variable. It should look as follows:

    -Dspring.profiles.active=ps-database,ptc-remote

    Warning

    If Orchestrator runs on the same application server as Backbase Portal Foundation, spring.profiles.active includes a profile for Orchestrator: orchestrator-database_server. Do not remove this profile.

  3. Deploy the WAR file

    The mashup-web-5.2.1.0.war file is located in the war folder in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.2.1.2.zip). Rename the WAR file to mashupservices.war and deploy it on a supported application server. Make sure to set the application context to mashupservices.

  4. Test installation

    Point your browser to the Mashup Services URL:

    http://host:port/applicationcontext/proxy

    The URL consists of the following parts:

How to Set an Environment Entry

You can set an environment entry in the WAR file or in the application server. Usually it is better to declare environment entries in the application server, because that method does not involve changing the WAR file. The procedure differs per application server, see the following list. If you prefer to change the WAR file, see the method below this list.

  • Apache Tomcat

    Open the tomcat_install_dir/conf/context.xml file and add the following tag:

    <Environment name="environment_entry_name"
    value="full_path_and_file_name"
    type="java.lang.String" override="false"/>

    Set override to false to ensure that an entry in the web.xml file does not override this environment entry.

  • WebSphere

    Follow these steps in the Integrated Solutions Console:

    1. Go to Servers > Application Servers and click on the server name.

    2. In the Server Infrastructure menu, click on Java and Process Management and Process definition.

    3. In the Additional Properties menu, click on Environment Entries.

    4. Click on the New button.

    5. Enter environment_entry_name in the Name field.

      Fill out the Value field with the full_path_and_file_name of the configuration file.

  • JBoss

    Follow these steps:

    1. Create a file jboss-web.xml. Store the file in the WEB-INF folder in the unpacked WAR file. Add the following content:

      <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<jboss-web>
    <resource-env-ref>
        <resource-env-ref-name>environment_entry_name</resource-env-ref-name>
        <jndi-name>jndi_binding_name</jndi-name>
    </resource-env-ref>
</jboss-web>

      Duplicate the resource-env-ref tag for additional environment entries.

    2. Create a file applicationcontext-service.xml. The applicationcontext usually reflects the name of the deployed WAR file, for example portalserver, mashupservices, contentservices or orchestrator. Store the file in jboss_install_dirserver/default/deploy. Add the following content:

      <mbean code="org.jboss.naming.JNDIBindingServiceMgr"
       name="jboss.apps:name=portalserver">
    <attribute name="BindingsConfig" serialDataType="jbxb">
        <jndi:bindings xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
                       xmlns:jndi="urn:jboss:jndi-binding-service:1.0"
                       xs:schemaLocation="urn:jboss:jndi-binding-service resource:jndi-binding-service_1_0.xsd">
            <jndi:binding name="jndi_binding_name">
                <jndi:value type="java.lang.String">full_path_and_file_name</jndi:value>
            </jndi:binding>
        </jndi:bindings>
    </attribute>
</mbean>

      Duplicate the jndi:binding tag for additional environment entries.

  • Jetty

    When working with the portal project running on Jetty, please use the web.xml method described below.

To set the environment entry directly in the WAR file: add the environment entry to the web.xml file located in src/main/webapp/WEB-INF in your portal project or WEB-INF in the unpacked WAR file:

<env-entry>
    <env-entry-name>environment_entry_name</env-entry-name>
    <env-entry-value>full_path_and_file_name</env-entry-value>
    <env-entry-type>java.lang.String</env-entry-type>
</env-entry>
