3 Development Setup

3.1. Create Project
3.1.1. Maven Settings File
3.2. Database setup (optional)
3.3. POM File
3.4. Import File
3.5. Portal Example
3.6. Test

Backbase Portal is available as a Maven project. Delivering Backbase Portal as a Maven project makes customization easier because Maven allows you to setup your portal project with minimal effort. At the Backbase Repository, a project template (archetype) is available.

Development Setup Prerequisites

To setup a portal project, the machine needs to meet the following requirements:

  • A supported operating system, see Operating Systems.

  • Maven version 3.

  • A Backbase Repository account.

    To request an account, please contact Backbase Support at www.backbase.com/services/support.

  • Java Developer Kit, see JDK.

Development Setup Procedure

The main steps of the development setup include:

  1. Create the Maven project

    See Create Project.

  2. Proxy configuration

    The modules of Backbase Portal use proxy configurations to be aware of each other URLs. See Proxy Configuration.

  3. Setup database (optional)

    By default, the Maven project uses an embedded H2 Database Engine. If you want to configure H2 Database Engine, or if you want to use a different database, see Database setup (optional).

  4. Change POM file

    See POM File.

  5. Create import file

    See Import File.

  6. Create a portal (optional)

    See Portal Example.

  7. Test the portal

    See Test.

After the development setup, you can start customizing the portal. For more information, see Customization.

Package the Project

To package the portal project in a WAR file, open a command shell and go to the project folder. Run the following command:

mvn package

Maven will create a WAR file in the target folder.

You can deploy the WAR file on an application server as described in Installation.

3.1 Create Project

Follow these steps to create the portal project:

  1. Maven setup

    1. Create or open the settings.xml file in the .m2 folder. The default location of the .m2 folder depends on the operating system:

      • On Microsoft Windows — C:\Documents and Settings\your_windows_username\.m2

      • On Unix — ~/.m2

      If Maven has never run, the .m2 folder does not exist. If so, create it manually.

    2. Copy the content of this Maven Settings File to your settings file and enter your username and password at the bottom. If you do not have a username, please contact Backbase Support at www.backbase.com/services/support to request an account.

  2. Comodo certificate

    The https://repo.backbase.com/repo/ repository uses SSL authentication and a Comodo addtrustexternalca certificate must be present in your Java Runtime Environment (JRE) keystore.

    1. To list all certificates, run the following command. On Unix machines, prepend the command with ./.

      keytool -list -keystore path_to_keystore/cacerts

      The default password for the Java default keystore is changeit.

    2. If the addtrustexternalca certificate is not listed, download it from the Comodo website and import it by running the following command. On Unix machines, prepend the command with ./.

      keytool -import -trustcacerts -alias comodoaaaca -file path_to_file/AddTrustExternalCARoot.crt -keystore path_to_keystore/cacerts

    3. Check that the addtrustexternalca certificate is listed in the JRE keystore by once again running the keytool command as described in Step 2.a.

  3. Generate project

    Open a command shell and go to a location where you want to create the portal project. Execute the following command:

    mvn archetype:generate -DarchetypeArtifactId=backbase-portal-archetype-blank -DarchetypeGroupId=com.backbase.portal.archetypes -DarchetypeVersion=5.2.1.2

  4. Enter project parameters

    In response to a series of command line prompts, set the following parameters:

    • groupId — a fully qualified package name identifying the organization, such as my.company.com.

    • artifactId — an identifier for the portal project, such as mycompany-portal. This setting defines the name of the folder in which the project is created.

    • version — defines the version of the portal project. The default value is 1.0-SNAPSHOT.

    • package — a fully qualified package name identifying the package, such as my.company.com. Defaults to the value of groupId.

    Finally, confirm the settings.

    The project is now created in the folder defined by artifactId.

You have finished creating a project. Continue with Proxy Configuration.

Top

3.1.1 Maven Settings File

The Maven settings file (settings.xml in the .m2 folder) should look as follows.

Note

Enter your username and password at the bottom of the file.

<settings xmlns="http://maven.apache.org/SETTINGS/1.0.0"
          xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
          xsi:schemaLocation="http://maven.apache.org/SETTINGS/1.0.0
                              http://maven.apache.org/xsd/settings-1.0.0.xsd">
    <profiles>
        <profile>
            <id>backbase</id>
            <activation>
                <activeByDefault>true</activeByDefault>
            </activation>
            <repositories>
                <repository>
                    <id>Backbase Artifact Repository</id>
                    <url>https://repo.backbase.com/repo/</url>
                </repository>
            </repositories>
        </profile>
    </profiles>
    <servers>
        <server>
            <id>Backbase Artifact Repository</id>
            <username>your_username</username>
            <password>your_password</password>
        </server>
    </servers>
</settings>

Continue with Step 2 of the Create Project topic.

Top

3.2 Database setup (optional)

Backbase Portal ships with an embedded H2 Database Engine. This section explains how to to configure the behavior of H2 Database Engine, or use a different database.

H2 Database Engine

The embedded H2 Database Engine is already configured. You can modify the configuration in the pom.xml file in your portal project. The relevant parameters are within the configuration element of the sql-maven-plugin plugin:

<configuration>
    <driver>org.h2.Driver</driver>
    <url>jdbc:h2:file:~/.backbase/portalFoundationBlankArchetype</url>
    <username>sa</username>
    <password></password>
    <srcFiles>
        <srcFile>${project.basedir}/configuration/schema.ddl</srcFile>
        <srcFile>${project.basedir}/configuration/default-data-foundation-blank.sql</srcFile>
    </srcFiles>
</configuration>

The H2 Database Engine JDBC driver.

The location of the database file. Note that multiple projects on the same machine overwrite the database file in the default location, so you might want to change this parameter.

The database username.

The database password.

The location of the schema.dll script in your portal project.

The location of the default-data-foundation-blank.sql script in your portal project.

The jetty.xml file in the configuration folder contains the database datasource definition:

<New id="portalDS" class="org.eclipse.jetty.plus.jndi.Resource">
    <Arg>jdbc/portalDS</Arg>
    <Arg>
        <New class="com.mchange.v2.c3p0.ComboPooledDataSource">
            <Set name="driverClass">org.h2.Driver</Set>
            <Set name="jdbcUrl">jdbc:h2:file:~/.backbase/portalFoundationBlankArchetype;MVCC=true;DB_CLOSE_ON_EXIT=FALSE</Set>
            <Set name="user">sa</Set>
            <Set name="password"></Set>
        </New>
    </Arg>
</New>

The datasource name.

The H2 Database Engine JDBC class.

The database file location. It must match the location in the pom.xml file.

The database username.

The database password.

Continue to POM File.

MySQL

  1. Open configuration file

    In Microsoft Windows, open or create the my.ini configuration file in the installation folder of MySQL. In Unix, open the /etc/mysql/my.cnf file. You can also create a database-specific configuration file.

  2. Set InnoDB storage engine

    Add the following to the [mysqld] section of the MySQL configuration file:

    default-storage-engine = innodb

  3. Set transaction isolation level

    Add the following to the [mysqld] section of the MySQL configuration file:

    transaction-isolation = READ-COMMITTED

  4. Setup UTF-8 support

    Add the following to the [mysqld] section of the MySQL configuration file:

    init_connect='SET collation_connection = utf8_general_ci'
init_connect='SET NAMES utf8'
character-set-server=utf8
collation-server=utf8_general_ci
skip-character-set-client-handshake

    Add the following to the [mysql] section of the MySQL configuration file, or replace the property value if it is already defined:

    default-character-set=utf8

  5. Restart MySQL

Follow these steps using MySQL Workbench or another MySQL tool:

  1. Create schema

    Make sure the MySQL is running and log in as root.

    Create a database, a user, and grant the user privileges on the database as shown below:

    • Create a database:

      CREATE SCHEMA database;

    • Select the schema:

      USE database;

    • Create a user, assign it a password, and give it rights on the schema created in the previous step:

      CREATE USER 'bb_user'@'localhost' IDENTIFIED BY 'password';
GRANT ALL PRIVILEGES on bb_portal.* to 'bb_user'@'localhost';
FLUSH PRIVILEGES;

  2. Populate the database

    Run the schema.ddl and default-foundation-data-blank.sql scripts to populate the database. These scripts are located in configuration/scripts/mysql in your portal project.

    • Run the schema.ddl script to create the database objects, or copy the file contents and paste them to the MySQL command line.

    • Run the default-foundation-data-blank.sql script to populate the database with a minimal data set. To run the script from the command line, type the following:

      mysql -uroot -ppassword database_name < default-foundation-data-blank.sql

    Note

    If you need to drop all schemas and re-configure the database, run the drop_schema.sql script located in configuration/scripts/mysql in your portal project.

  3. Add JDBC driver dependency

    Open the pom.xml file in your project root folder and add the following dependency to the jetty-maven-plugin definition:

    <dependency>
    <groupId>mysql</groupId>
    <artifactId>mysql-connector-java</artifactId>
    <version>5.1.9</version>
    <scope>runtime</scope>
</dependency>

  4. Remove sql-maven-plugin

    In the pom.xml file, remove or comment out the whole sql-maven-plugin plugin definition.

  5. Configure datasource

    Open the jetty.xml file in the configuration folder in your portal project and modify the datasource definition:

    <New id="portalDS" class="org.eclipse.jetty.plus.jndi.Resource">
    <Arg>jdbc/portalDS</Arg>
    <Arg>
        <New class="com.mchange.v2.c3p0.ComboPooledDataSource">
            <Set name="driverClass">com.mysql.jdbc.Driver</Set>
            <Set name="jdbcUrl">jdbc:mysql://localhost:3306/database</Set>
            <Set name="user">username</Set>
            <Set name="password">password</Set>
        </New>
    </Arg>
</New>

    The datasource name.

    The MySQL JDBC class.

    The database URL.

    The user you created in the previous steps.

    The password you defined in the previous steps.

Continue to POM File.

Oracle

  1. Download JDBC driver

    Select a compatible driver for your database and JDK version: Oracle 11 JDBC Drivers

  2. Add JDBC driver to local Maven repository

    Add the JDBC driver to your local Maven repository with the following command:

    mvn install:install-file -Dfile=ojdbcx.jar -DgroupId=com.oracle -DartifactId=ojdbcx -Dversion=oracle_version -Dpackaging=jar

    Make sure you enter the correct JDBC and Oracle version numbers.

  3. Create user

    Make sure Oracle is running and log into the SQLPlus command line tool as administrator.

    Create a user, grant it privileges, and grant unlimited tablespace as shown below:

    CREATE USER username
PROFILE DEFAULT
IDENTIFIED BY password
DEFAULT TABLESPACE users
TEMPORARY TABLESPACE temp
ACCOUNT UNLOCK;

GRANT CREATE SESSION, CREATE TABLE, CREATE PROCEDURE,
CREATE SEQUENCE, CREATE VIEW, CREATE TRIGGER,
CREATE SYNONYM, CREATE MATERIALIZED VIEW,
QUERY REWRITE, CREATE ANY DIRECTORY, CREATE TYPE
TO username;

GRANT UNLIMITED TABLESPACE TO username;

  4. Populate the database

    Log in with the user you just created and run the schema.ddl and default-foundation-data-blank.sql scripts to populate the database. These scripts are located in configuration/scripts/oracle in your portal project.

    First, navigate to the directory that holds the scripts. Then, use the following commands:

    @schema.ddl
@default-foundation-data-blank.sql

    Note

    If you need to drop all schemas and re-configure the database, run the drop_schema.sql script located in configuration/scripts/oracle in your portal project.

  5. Add JDBC driver dependency

    Open the pom.xml file in your project root folder and add the following dependency to the jetty-maven-plugin definition:

    <dependency>
    <groupId>com.oracle</groupId>
    <artifactId>ojdbcx</artifactId>
    <version>version</version>
    <scope>runtime</scope>
</dependency>

    Enter the JDBC and Oracle version numbers so that they match what you entered in Step 2.

  6. Remove sql-maven-plugin

    In the pom.xml file, remove or comment out the whole sql-maven-plugin plugin definition.

  7. Configure datasource

    Open the jetty.xml file in the configuration folder in your portal project and modify the datasource definition:

    <New id="portalDS" class="org.eclipse.jetty.plus.jndi.Resource">
    <Arg>jdbc/portalDS</Arg>
    <Arg>
        <New class="com.mchange.v2.c3p0.ComboPooledDataSource">
            <Set name="driverClass">oracle.jdbc.driver.OracleDriver</Set>
            <Set name="jdbcUrl">jdbc:oracle:thin:@localhost:1521/database</Set>
            <Set name="user">username</Set>
            <Set name="password">password</Set>
        </New>
    </Arg>
</New>

    The datasource name.

    The Oracle JDBC class.

    The database URL. Replace database with the database you created in the previous steps. If you are using Oracle XE, replace database with XE.

    Replace username with the user you created in the previous steps.

    Replace with the database password you defined in the previous steps.

Continue to POM File.

IBM DB2

  1. Download JDBC driver

    Select a compatible driver for your database version: DB2 JDBC Drivers

    The downloaded archive will contain a JAR file for JDBC 4.0, e.g. db2jcc4.jar

  2. Add JDBC driver to local Maven repository

    Add the JDBC driver to your local Maven repository with the following command:

    mvn install:install-file -Dfile=db2jcc4.jar -DgroupId=com.ibm.db2 -DartifactId=db2jcc -Dpackaging=jar

  3. Create database

    Follow these steps using the IBM DB2 Configuration assistant and Control Center:

    • Create a database

      Right-click on All Databases, select Create Database..., and pick Standard. In the resulting screen give a database name, change the codeset to UTF-8 and click on Finish.

    • Create user

      Create a user account on the operating system.

    • Create schema

    • Grant rights on schema

      Give the user created in the previous step rights on the database. Add the schema created in the previous step to the user and grant all rights on that schema.

  4. Connect to the database

    Use the following command:

    db2 connect to [database] user [username] using [password]

    For example:

    db2 connect to portal5 user backbase using bb1234

  5. Populate the database

    Run the schema.ddl and default-foundation-data-blank.sql scripts to populate the database. These scripts are located in configuration/scripts/db2 in your portal project.

    First, navigate to the directory that holds the scripts. Then, use the following commands:

    db2 -td; -vf schema.ddl
db2 -td@ -vf default-foundation-data-blank.sql

    Note

    If you need to drop all schemas and re-configure the database, run the drop_schema.sql script located in configuration/scripts/db2 in your portal project.

  6. Download IBM DB2 JDBC driver

    Select a compatible driver for your database version and save it on the file system: DB2 JDBC Drivers

    The downloaded archive will contain a JAR file for JDBC 4.0, e.g. db2jcc4.jar

  7. Add JDBC driver dependency

    Open the pom.xml file in your project root folder and add the following dependency to the jetty-maven-plugin definition:

    <dependency>
    <groupId>com.ibm.db2</groupId>
    <artifactId>db2jcc</artifactId>
    <version>db2_level</version>
    <type>jar</type>
    <scope>system</scope>
    <systemPath>path/to/db2jcc.jar</systemPath>
</dependency>

    Replace db2_level with your IBM DB2 version, and path/to/db2jcc.jar with the file system location of the JDBC driver you downloaded in the previous step.

  8. Add license dependency (version-dependent)

    Some IBM DB2 versions require a license file named db2jcc_license_cisuz.jar. For an overview of IBM DB2 versions, see the IBM Support Portal.

    If your IBM DB2 version requires the db2jcc_license_cisuz.jar file, add the following dependency to the pom.xml file:

    <dependency>
    <groupId>com.ibm.db2</groupId>
    <artifactId>db2jcc_license_cisuz</artifactId>
    <version>db2_level</version>
    <type>jar</type>
    <scope>system</scope>
    <systemPath>path/to/db2jcc_license_cisuz.jar</systemPath>
</dependency>

    Replace db2_level with your IBM DB2 version, and path/to/db2jcc_license_cisuz.jar with the file system location of the db2jcc_license_cisuz.jar license file.

  9. Remove sql-maven-plugin

    In the pom.xml file, remove or comment out the whole sql-maven-plugin plugin definition.

  10. Configure datasource

    Open the jetty.xml file in the configuration folder in your portal project and modify the datasource definition:

    <New id="portalDS" class="org.eclipse.jetty.plus.jndi.Resource">
    <Arg>jdbc/portalDS</Arg>
    <Arg>
        <New class="com.mchange.v2.c3p0.ComboPooledDataSource">
            <Set name="driverClass">com.ibm.db2.jcc.DB2Driver</Set>
            <Set name="jdbcUrl">jdbc:db2://localhost:50000/database</Set>
            <Set name="user">username</Set>
            <Set name="password">password</Set>
        </New>
    </Arg>
</New>

    The datasource name.

    The IBM DB2 JDBC class.

    The database URL. Replace database with the database you created in the previous steps.

    Replace username with the user you created in the previous steps.

    The database password you defined in the previous steps.

Continue to POM File.

Microsoft SQL Server

  1. Download JDBC driver

    Download the Microsoft SQL Server JDBC Driver and store in on your file system.

  2. Add JDBC driver to local Maven repository

    Add the JDBC driver to your local Maven repository with the following command:

    mvn install:install-file -Dfile=sqljdbc4.jar -DgroupId=com.microsoft.sqlserver -DartifactId=sqljdbc4 -Dversion=3.0 -Dpackaging=jar

  3. Create database and user

    Follow these steps using Microsoft SQL Server Management Studio:

    1. Log in as system administrator

    2. Create database

    3. Set transaction isolation level

      Run the following commands on the database you just created:

      ALTER DATABASE database_name SET READ_COMMITTED_SNAPSHOT ON
ALTER DATABASE database_name SET ALLOW_SNAPSHOT_ISOLATION ON

    4. Create schema

    5. Create user

      In the login properties, set the created database and schema as default for this user. Make the user dbowner of the database.

  4. Populate the database

    Run the schema.ddl and default-foundation-data-blank.sql scripts to populate the database. These scripts are located in configuration/scripts/sqlserver in your portal project.

    Note

    If you need to drop all schemas and re-configure the database, run the drop_schema.sql script located in configuration/scripts/sqlserver2008 in your portal project.

  5. Remove sql-maven-plugin

    In the pom.xml file, remove or comment out the whole sql-maven-plugin plugin definition.

  6. Configure datasource

    Open the jetty.xml file in the configuration folder in your portal project and modify the datasource definition:

    <New id="portalDS" class="org.eclipse.jetty.plus.jndi.Resource">
    <Arg>jdbc/portalDS</Arg>
    <Arg>
        <New class="com.mchange.v2.c3p0.ComboPooledDataSource">
            <Set name="driverClass">com.microsoft.sqlserver.jdbc.SQLServerDriver</Set>
            <Set name="jdbcUrl">jdbc:microsoft:sqlserver://localhost:1433;databaseName=database</Set>
            <Set name="user">username</Set>
            <Set name="password">password</Set>
        </New>
    </Arg>
</New>

    The datasource name.

    The IBM DB2 JDBC class.

    The database URL. Replace database with the database you created in the previous steps.

    Replace username with the user you created in the previous steps.

    The database password you defined in the previous steps.

Continue to POM File.

Top

3.3 POM File

Adjust the pom.xml file located in the root folder of your portal project.

  1. Set log folder

    Add the following system property to the jetty-maven-plugin plugin configuration:

    <systemProperty>
    <name>PORTALSERVER_LOG_FOLDER</name>
    <value>${project.build.directory}/logs</value>
</systemProperty>

  2. Set Spring profile (optional)

    This step is only necessary if you want to use a database other than H2, or if you want to use a stand-alone version of Mashup Services. Add the following system property to the jetty-maven-plugin plugin configuration:

    <systemProperty>
    <name>spring.profiles.active</name>
    <value>ps-database_server,ptc-[local|remote]</value>
</systemProperty>

    1. Replace database_server with the database of Backbase Portal Foundation:

      Table 3.1. Database Parameters

      Database

      Parameter

      MySQL

      mysql

      Oracle

      oracle

      IBM DB2

      db2

      Microsoft SQL Server

      sqlserver

      H2 Database Engine

      h2

      If you do not specify the ps-database_server profile, Backbase Portal Foundation defaults to H2 Database Engine.


    2. Set [local|remote] to local if you want to use Mashup Services embedded in Backbase Portal Foundation. Set it to remote if you have installed Mashup Services stand-alone. If you do not specify the ptc-[local|remote] profile, Backbase Portal Foundation defaults to local.

      Note that if you set the profile to ptc-remote, the embedded instance of Mashup Services is disabled.

    For example, the parameter for MySQL and Mashup Services stand-alone is as follows:

    -Dspring.profiles.active=ps-mysql,ptc-remote

    Warning

    If Orchestrator runs on the same application server as Backbase Portal Foundation, spring.profiles.active should also include a profile for Orchestrator: orchestrator-database_server. For more information, see Orchestrator.

    Warning

    Either specify all profiles or none. If you only specify some of the profiles, these will be ignored and the defaults will be used instead.

  3. Set the logging language to English (optional)

    Find the portalserver.language systemProperty in the jetty-maven-plugin plugin configuration. Change the value from the default nl (Dutch) to en for logging in English. If this systemProperty is missing, the Jetty server will default to English.

  4. Java version

    You can set the Java compliance level in the <source> and <target> parameters in the maven-compiler-plugin plugin. See JDK for the supported Java versions.

You have finished changing the POM file. Continue with Import File.

Top

3.4 Import File

Copy one of the shipped import files:

  • To run Backbase Portal Manager and Shipped Bundles: copy the file src/main/dashboardResources/import/importPortal.xml in your portal project to src/main/resources/import.

    If you prefer to disable the publishing functionality, remove the following widget from the dashboard portal:

    <widgets>
    <file>backbase.com.2012.tango/instance-widgets.xml</file>
</widgets>

    Note

    You might notice that several file locations and parameters concerning Backbase Portal Manager use the term Spitfire and Dashboard. Spitfire and Dashboard are synonyms of Backbase Portal Manager.

  • To run without Backbase Portal Manager shipped bundles: copy the file src/main/coreResources/import/importPortal.xml in your portal project to src/main/resources/import.

For more information, see Import File.

You have finished with the import file. Continue with Portal Example (optional).

Top

3.5 Portal Example

This is an optional step. The portal project is now empty (contains no portals or pages). Follow these instructions to create a portal with one page, container and widget.

  1. Create a widget definition

    The portal will include a 'Hello World' widget. The widget definition is an XHTML file that defines the HTML representation of the widget. Create the folders static/doctest/widgets/helloworld in src/main/webapp in your portal project. In the helloworld folder, create a file named index.html with the following content:

    <!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN"
 "http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd">
<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xml:lang="en">
    <head>
        <meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8"/>
        <title>Hello World</title>
    </head>
    <body>
        <p>Hello World</p>
    </body>
</html>

  2. Change import file

    Open the importPortal.xml file in src/main/resources/import in your portal project. Add this tag to the <!-- ** PORTALS ** --> section:

        <!-- Doctest -->
    <portal-import>
        <name>Doctest</name>
        <file>portals/doctest/portal.xml</file>
        <catalog>
            <file>portals/doctest/catalog.xml</file>
        </catalog>
        <containers>
            <file>portals/doctest/containers.xml</file>
        </containers>
        <widgets>
            <file>portals/doctest/widgets.xml</file>
        </widgets>
        <links>
            <file>portals/doctest/links.xml</file>
        </links>
    </portal-import>

  3. Create folder for portal import files

    Create the folders named portals/doctest in src/main/resources/import in your portal project.

  4. Portal

    Create a file named portal.xml in src/main/resources/import/portals/doctest. Add the following content:

    <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<portal>
    <name>doctest</name>
    <contextItemName>[BBHOST]</contextItemName>
    <properties>
        <property name="DefaultLandingPage">
            <value type="string">index</value>
        </property>
        <property name="DefaultDevice">
            <value type="string">web</value>
        </property>
        <property name="TargetedDevice">
            <value type="string">web</value>
        </property>
        <property name="title"><value type="string">Doctest Portal</value></property>
    </properties>
    <children>
        <page>
            <name>index</name>
            <uuid>15</uuid>
            <contextItemName>doctest</contextItemName>
            <parentItemName>doctest</parentItemName>
            <properties>
                <property name="TemplateName">
                    <value type="string">Page_Default</value>
                </property>
                <property name="title">
                    <value type="string">Doctest Portal - Index</value>
                </property>
            </properties>
        </page>
    </children>
</portal>

    Tip

    The template comes from a shipped bundle, see Aurora.

  5. Catalog

    Create a file named catalog.xml in src/main/resources/import/portals/doctest. Add the following content:

    <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<catalog>
    <widget>
        <name>hello_world_widget</name>
        <contextItemName>doctest</contextItemName>
        <properties>
            <property name="TemplateName">
                <value type="string">Standard_Widget</value>
            </property>
            <property name="src">
                <value type="string">$(contextRoot)/static/doctest/widgets/helloworld/index.html</value>
            </property>
            <property name="widgetChrome" label="Widget Chrome">
                <value type="string">$(contextRoot)/static/backbase.com.2012.aurora/html/chromes/widget_default.html</value>
            </property>
            <property name="area"><value type="string">west</value></property>
            <property name="order"><value type="double">1.0</value></property>
            <property name="title">
                <value type="string">Hello World Widget</value>
            </property>
            <!-- Only Backbase Portal Manager uses the following property -->
            <property name="thumbnailUrl">
                <value type="string">$(contextRoot)/static/dashboard/media/icons/icons-widgets_01-default.png</value>
            </property>
        </properties>
    </widget>
</catalog>

    Tip

    Note that the properties refer to the widget definition created earlier.

  6. Containers

    Create a file named containers.xml in src/main/resources/import/portals/doctest. Add the following content:

    <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<containers>
    <container>
        <name>doc_test_container</name>
        <contextItemName>doctest</contextItemName>
        <parentItemName>index</parentItemName>
        <properties>
            <property name="TemplateName">
                <value type="string">Border_table</value>
            </property>
            <property name="rowHeights">
                <value type="string">100px,100px,100px</value>
            </property>
            <property name="midColWidths">
                <value type="string">100px,100px,100px</value>
            </property>
        </properties>
    </container>
</containers>

    Tip

    The template comes from a shipped bundle, see Aurora.

  7. Widgets

    Create a file named widgets.xml in src/main/resources/import/portals/doctest. Add the following content:

    <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<widgets>
    <widget>
        <name>hello_world_widget1</name>
        <extendedItemName>hello_world_widget</extendedItemName>
        <contextItemName>doctest</contextItemName>
        <parentItemName>doc_test_container</parentItemName>
    </widget>
</widgets>

    Tip

    Note that this widget extends the widget in the catalog (it will inherit its properties).

  8. Links

    Create a file named links.xml in src/main/resources/import/portals/doctest. Add the following content:

    <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<links>
    <link>
        <name>navroot_mainmenu</name>
        <contextItemName>doctest</contextItemName>
        <parentItemName>doctest</parentItemName>
        <properties>
            <property name="title">
                <value type="string">Navigation</value>
            </property>
            <property name="itemType">
                <value type="string">menuHeader</value>
            </property>
        </properties>
    </link>
    <link>
        <name>navroot_notinmenu</name>
        <contextItemName>doctest</contextItemName>
        <parentItemName>doctest</parentItemName>
        <properties>
            <property name="title">
                <value type="string">Floating Pages</value>
            </property>
            <property name="itemType">
                <value type="string">menuHeader</value>
            </property>
        </properties>
    </link>
    <link>
        <name>indexLink</name>
        <contextItemName>doctest</contextItemName>
        <parentItemName>navroot_mainmenu</parentItemName>
        <properties>
            <property name="title">
                <value type="string">Index</value>
            </property>
            <property name="ItemRef">
                <value type="string">15</value>
            </property>
            <property name="itemType">
                <value type="string">page</value>
            </property>
        </properties>
    </link>
</links>

This concludes the portal example. You can now start to Test the portal.

Top

3.6 Test

Follow these steps to test the project:

  1. Run the project

    Open a command shell and go to the project folder. Execute the following commands: 

    mvn -P with-dashboard clean install
mvn jetty:run-war

    The last command starts a Jetty server with an instance of an embedded H2 Database Engine and deploys the portal on it. The -P modifier sets the Maven profile to with-dashboard. Exclude this modifier to run Backbase Portal without Backbase Portal Manager.

  2. Run the importer tool

    Open http://host:port/applicationcontext/import in a browser. The URL consists of the following parts:

    Table 3.2. Backbase Portal Foundation URL Parts

    URL Part

    Default

    Description

    host

    localhost

    The host name of the server that hosts Backbase Portal Foundation.

    port

    Jetty: 7777

    Apache Tomcat: 8080

    WebSphere: 9080

    JBoss: 8080

    When running the portal project, it uses an (embedded) Jetty server. You can set the port in the application server settings.

    applicationcontext

    portalserver

    This value usually reflects the name of the deployed WAR file.


    Log in with the administrator username admin and password admin. To load the login page directly, navigate to http://host:port/applicationcontext/spring_security_login. The following screen opens:

    All objects should be checked (this is default). Click Import. If the import was successful, no message is shown.

    For more information on the importer tool, see Importer.

    Note

    As long as you use the default H2 Database Engine, you need to run the importer tool each time you test the portal project.

  3. Open the portal example

    Open http://host:port/applicationcontext/portals/doctest in a browser. You should see a page with a log out link, the username admin and a widget. You can drag the widget to another location on the page.

  4. Open Backbase Portal Manager

    Open the following URL: http://host:port/applicationcontext/portals/dashboard.

    Note

    You might notice that several file locations and parameters concerning Backbase Portal Manager use the term Dashboard. Dashboard is a synonym for Backbase Portal Manager.

Note

For more information on the URLs of Backbase Portal, see the REST API. There are a number of third-party tools to directly communicate to the REST interface. For more information, see Third-party Tools.

4.1 Migrating from 5.2.0 to 5.2.1

If you are upgrading Backbase Portal from version 5.2.0 to version 5.2.1, you need to make the following changes:

  • Database

    Run database migration scripts, see Database Migration.

  • MySQL on Unix

    If you are running MySQL on Unix, disable identifier case sensitivity. You can skip the following steps if you are running Microsoft Windows:

    1. Open the /etc/mysql/my.cnf file.

    2. Add the following line under the [mysqld] group definition:

      lower_case_table_names=2

    3. Restart MySQL.

    To test that the change had the desired effect, log in MySQL and check that the following does not return an error:

    CREATE SCHEMA CaSeInSenSiTiVe;
USE caseinsensitive;

  • ItemRef property

    The ItemRef property in the link object now refers to the uuid of the page, not the name. Run database migration scripts to correct your data.

  • Update web.xml

    The web.xml file has changed. Follow these steps to update it:

    • If you are going to use Backbase Portal Manager, add the following lines after the other context parameters:

      <context-param>
    <param-name>com.backbase.portal.ptc.web.PROPERTIES_FILE</param-name>
    <param-value>classpath:/ice-config.properties,jndi:java:comp/env/portalmanager/ice-config</param-value>
</context-param>
<env-entry>
    <env-entry-name>portalmanager/ice-config</env-entry-name>
    <env-entry-type>java.lang.String</env-entry-type>
</env-entry>

    • Change the uAgentInfoGatheringFilter to the following:

      <filter>
    <filter-name>uAgentInfoGatheringFilter</filter-name>
    <filter-class>org.springframework.web.filter.DelegatingFilterProxy
    </filter-class>
</filter>

    • Add the urlFilter after springSecurityFilterChain filter:

      <filter>
    <filter-name>urlFilter</filter-name>
    <filter-class>org.springframework.web.filter.DelegatingFilterProxy
    </filter-class>
</filter>

    • Add the urlFilter mapping after the springSecurityFilterChain mapping:

      <filter-mapping>
    <filter-name>urlFilter</filter-name>
    <servlet-name>Portal Foundation Spring MVC</servlet-name>
</filter-mapping>

    • Remove the following lines:

      <!-- Handles PTC requests -->
<servlet>
    <servlet-name>ProxyServlet</servlet-name>
    <servlet-class>com.backbase.portal.ptc.ProxyServlet</servlet-class>
    <load-on-startup>2</load-on-startup>
</servlet>

<servlet-mapping>
    <servlet-name>ProxyServlet</servlet-name>
    <url-pattern>/proxy/*</url-pattern>
</servlet-mapping>

  • Update portal.tld

    The tag library definition has changed. Add the following lines at the bottom of the portal.tld file:

    <tag>
    <name>tabContainerInit</name>
    <tag-class>com.backbase.portal.foundation.presentation.renderer.TabContainerInitTag
    </tag-class>
    <body-content>empty</body-content>
    <attribute>
        <name>src</name>
        <required>true</required>
        <rtexprvalue>true</rtexprvalue>
    </attribute>
</tag>
<tag>
    <name>areaSort</name>
    <tag-class>com.backbase.portal.foundation.presentation.renderer.AreaSortTag
    </tag-class>
    <body-content>empty</body-content>
    <attribute>
        <name>src</name>
        <required>true</required>
        <rtexprvalue>true</rtexprvalue>
    </attribute>
</tag>

  • Changed profile configuration

    Run your application server with the following parameter or add it to the JAVA_OPTS environment variable:

    -Dspring.profiles.active=ps-database_server,ptc-[local|remote]

    1. Replace database_server with the database of Backbase Portal Foundation:

      Table 4.1. Database Parameters

      Database

      Parameter

      MySQL

      mysql

      Oracle

      oracle

      IBM DB2

      db2

      Microsoft SQL Server

      sqlserver

      H2 Database Engine

      h2

      If you do not specify the ps-database_server profile, Backbase Portal Foundation defaults to H2 Database Engine.


    2. Set [local|remote] to local if you want to use Mashup Services embedded in Backbase Portal Foundation. Set it to remote if you have installed Mashup Services stand-alone. If you do not specify the ptc-[local|remote] profile, Backbase Portal Foundation defaults to local.

      Note that if you set the profile to ptc-remote, the embedded instance of Mashup Services is disabled.

    For example, the parameter for MySQL and Mashup Services stand-alone is as follows:

    -Dspring.profiles.active=ps-mysql,ptc-remote

    Warning

    If Orchestrator runs on the same application server as Backbase Portal Foundation, spring.profiles.active should also include a profile for Orchestrator: orchestrator-database_server. For more information, see Orchestrator.

    Warning

    Either specify all profiles or none. If you only specify some of the profiles, these will be ignored and the defaults will be used instead.

Top

4.1.1 Database Migration

Follow the steps below to migrate the database to Backbase Portal version 5.2.1:

  1. Backup your database.

  2. Stop your application server.

  3. Go to the configuration/portalserver/scripts folder in the Backbase_Portal_5.2.1.zip archive and open the folder corresponding to your database engine (e.g. db2 for the DB2 database). Open the upgrade_5_2_0_to_5_2_1 folder and run the pre-dml-upgrade-5.2.0-to-5.2.1.ddl.

  4. Skip this step if you already created the sys2sys user in Backbase Portal 5.2.0. If you did not create it, run the add_sys2sys.ddl script.

  5. Run the upgrade-5.2.0-to-5.2.1.dml script.

  6. Restart the application server and deploy the new Backbase Portal version as described in Installation.

Note that each database folder contains a readme.txt file with further instructions.

Top

4.2 Migrating from 5.1 to 5.2

If you are upgrading Backbase Portal from version 5.1 to version 5.2, you need to make the following changes:

  • Locked field removed

    The locked field is removed from the item object. Objects that extend item are portal, page, container, widget, link and template. They no longer contain the locked field. Including this field in import scripts will result in an error.

  • Embedded Mashup Services installation changed

    Mashup Services is now always embedded in Backbase Portal Foundation. To accommodate this change, follow these steps:

    1. Open your POM file in the root folder of your portal project and remove the following dependency:

      <dependency>
    <groupId>com.backbase.services.mashup</groupId>
    <artifactId>mashup-embedded</artifactId>
    <version>${portal.mashup.version}</version>
</dependency>

    2. Open the web.xml file in the src/main/webapp/WEB-INF in your portal project and add the following servlet:

          <!-- Handles PTC requests -->
    <servlet>
        <servlet-name>ProxyServlet</servlet-name>
        <servlet-class>com.backbase.portal.ptc.ProxyServlet</servlet-class>
        <load-on-startup>2</load-on-startup>
    </servlet>

    <servlet-mapping>
        <servlet-name>ProxyServlet</servlet-name>
        <url-pattern>/proxy/*</url-pattern>
    </servlet-mapping>

  • Empty securityProfile no longer allowed

    Empty securityProfile is no longer allowed. Excluding securityProfile means the object will inherit security profile from parent. To remove rights, set securityProfile to NONE.

  • Database

    Run database migration scripts, see Database Migration.

  • Links

    Change your import XML files to make sure that each page has a corresponding link. Links should be children of a link with the name navroot_mainmenu or navroot_notinmenu.

  • Additional properties for portal

    Backbase Portal Manager expects these additional properties for a portal object: DefaultDevice and TargetedDevice.

  • Bundles

    Backbase Portal has implemented a best practice for ordering files and folders within a portal project. A bundle consists of import files, templates, JavaScript, media and styling. For more information, see Bundles.

  • Including Backbase Portal Client

    Instead of calling the JS script of Backbase Portal Client, you can now include the following JSP template:

    <jsp:include page="../../common/portalclient-libs.jsp"/>

    This template checks whether the page is being edited in Backbase Portal Manager (development mode), and adds the necessary scripts.

  • Backbase Portal Client initialization

    The function to initialize Backbase Portal Client has changed. The script in the page template header portal.init().fetchPage(); is replaced by a script in the body tag:

    <body onload="b$.portal.startup('main')">

    The parameter in the startup function is the id of the HTML element in which Backbase Portal Client will render the page.

  • Application context in src property

    The path of the widget property src used to start with static, now it should contain the context root: $(contextRoot)/static.

  • Custom client-side layouts

    The new Backbase Portal Client has no default client-side layouts. Instead, it offers the ability to create custom layouts. You can register a container client template that defines a custom layout, see How to Implement a Custom Layout. Also the bundles contain layouts you can use, see Bundles.

  • Property client-template

    This property is no longer used for client-side layouts. Backbase Portal Client now also looks at the TemplateName property. This has the implication that server-side and client-side templates need to have the same name. The server-side template name is set in the template object, the client-side template name is set when registering the template, see How to Implement a Custom Layout.

    For the shipped templates, see Bundles.

  • Property for thumbnail

    This property now has one name thumbnailUrl that replaces thumbnail and thumbnail-url.

  • Drop areas

    The class that Backbase Portal Client recognizes as drop area has changed from portal-area to bp-area.

  • Class ssr

    This class is no longer necessary for server-side rendered widgets.

  • Property RenderAtServer

    This property is no longer necessary for server-side rendered objects.

  • Property Title

    This property is renamed to title. Please change this in objects (pages, containers, widgets, templates), JSP templates and API calls.

  • Property template

    This widget property is no longer necessary. To indicate the widget type (Backbase or W3C), set the TemplateName to a widget template that renders either a Backbase or a W3C widget. For more information, see Widget Template.

Top

4.2.1 Database Migration

Follow the steps below to migrate the database to Backbase Portal version 5.2:

Warning

Use the scripts provided in the Backbase_Portal_5.2.1.zip archive or later, not those in Backbase_Portal_5.2.0.zip.

  1. Backup your database.

  2. Stop your application server before running the database scripts. This step is optional.

  3. Go to the resources/src/main/resources/scripts folder in the Backbase_Portal_5.2.1.zip archive and open the folder corresponding to your database engine (i.e. db2 for the DB2 database). Open the upgrade_5_1_2_to_5_2_0 folder and run the pre-dml-upgrade-5.1.2-to-5.2.0.ddl and upgrade-5.1.2-to-5.2.0.dml scripts.

  4. Deploy the new Backbase Portal version as described in Installation and, if necessary, restart the application server.

  5. Run the post-dml-upgrade-5.1.2-to-5.2.0.ddl script.

Note that each database folder contains a readme.txt file with further instructions.

Top

4.3 Migrating from 5.0.4 to 5.1

If you are upgrading Backbase Portal from version 5.0.4 to version 5.1, you need to modify your current page templates, container templates, and run some database migration scripts.

Top

4.3.1 Migrating Page Templates

Add Class

With release 5.1, the HTML element that contains the page must have a class attribute set to pageContainer. The portal.init function refers to this HTML element. In this example, Backbase Portal Client will render the page in the HTML element with id="mycontentarea": 

portal.init('${item.contextItemName}').fetchPage('${item.name}',
    '#mycontentarea');

The page template in the documentation for Backbase Portal version 5.0.4 defined the <div> tag as follows:

<div id="mycontentarea">
</div>

With the new version, this must change to:

<div id="mycontentarea" class="pageContainer">
</div>
Remove Redundant Script

The script below was necessary to run Backbase Portal Client, but is now redundant. Remove it from your page templates.

<script type="text/javascript">
 /* <![CDATA[ */
        b$ = {};
        b$.browser = (function() {
            var browser = {};
            // Simple browser detection - Internet Explorer
            if (document.all && !navigator.userAgent.match(/opera/i)
                && !navigator.appVersion.match(/mac/i)){
                browser.ie = true;
                browser.version = parseFloat(navigator.appVersion.substr(
                    navigator.appVersion.indexOf('MSIE ')+5, 3) );
                (function (){
                    try {
                        //PRE MSXML <3 support for example Windows 98/2000 machines
                        var oXml = new ActiveXObject('MSXML2.XSLTemplate');
                    } catch(oError) {
                        browser.ie = false;
                    }
                })();
            }
            return browser;
        })();
        /* ]]> */
    </script>

For more information, see Page Template.

Top

4.3.2 Migrating Container Templates

With release 5.1, for server-side rendered widgets, the containing <div> tag in a container template must have a class attribute set to ssr. For example, the following code from the default container shipped with Backbase Portal 5.0.4 renders a container and its children in the <div>:

<div class="portal-area">
    <c:forEach items="${my_items.children}" var="child">
        <c:if test='${child.propertyDefinitions["area"].value.value == "1"}'>
            <b:include src="${child}"/>
        </c:if>
    </c:forEach>
</div>

The <div> tag must now change to:

<div class="portal-area ssr">

For more information, see Client-side and Server-side Rendering.

Top

4.3.3 Database Migration

Follow the steps below to migrate the database to Backbase Portal version 5.1:

  1. Backup your database.

  2. Stop your application server before running the database scripts. This step is optional.

  3. Go to the resources/src/main/resources/scripts folder in the Backbase_Portal_5.1.0.zip archive and open the folder corresponding to your database engine (i.e. db2 for the DB2 database). Open the upgrade_5_0_4_to_5_1_0 folder and run the pre-dml-upgrade-5.0.4-to-5.1.0.ddl and upgrade-5.0.4-to-5.1.2.dml scripts.

  4. Deploy the new Backbase Portal version as described in Installation and, if necessary, restart the application server.

  5. Run the post-dml-upgrade-5.0.4-to-5.1.0.ddl script.

Note that each database folder contains a readme.txt file with further instructions.

Top

4.3.4 Migrating Content Services Database

Follow the steps below to migrate the Content Services database to Backbase Portal version 5.1:

  1. Backup the Content Services database.

  2. Stop your application server before running the database scripts. This step is optional.

  3. Go to the liquibase/sql folder in the repository.jar archive within the WEB-INF/lib folder of the Content Services installation directory. Run the script corresponding to your database engine (i.e. DB2_v501_to_v51.sql for IBM DB2).

  4. Deploy the Content Services WAR file as described in Content Services and, if necessary, restart the application server.

Note that the repository-5.2.1.0.jar/liquibase folder contains a readme.txt file with further instructions.

Top

5 Solving Problems

You can try the following actions to solve problems with Backbase Portal:

  • Check installation

    Check the installation procedure or development setup of the module. Every step is mandatory, except for the Development Setup: only the first step is mandatory, the other steps add Backbase Portal Manager and bundles to the project.

  • Clear browser cache

    Changes to Backbase Portal may not be visible, because your browser has cached data. Sometimes refreshing the page is not enough. Try clearing your browser cache:

    • Google Chrome

      Press Ctrl+Shift+Del to open the dialog, check Empty the cache and click Clear browsing data.

    • Mozilla Firefox

      Press Ctrl+Shift+Del to open the dialog, check Cache and click Clear Now.

    • Microsoft Internet Explorer

      Press Ctrl+Shift+Del to open the dialog, check Temporary Internet files and click Delete.

    • Apple Safari

      Press Option+Command+E (or go to Safari|Empty Cache... in the menu) to open the dialog and click Empty.

    • Opera

      Go to Settings|Delete Private Data... in the menu to open the dialog, select Delete entire cache and click Delete.

  • Perform migration actions

    When you have upgraded Backbase Portal, perform the migration actions, like running migration scripts, listed in Migration.

  • Same version across modules

    Using different versions of Backbase Portal modules may cause problems. Upgrade the modules to the shipped versions, see Package Contents. Perform the migration steps listed in Migration.

  • Upgrade Maven project from artifact

    When upgrading Backbase Portal, also upgrade the Maven project from the artifact, see Create Project.

  • Content Services drop tables

    If you want to delete the content of Content Services, you need to drop the tables configuration, content and resource and then also delete the folder C:\.backbase\contentservices on Microsoft Windows or /usr/home/username/.backbase/contentservices on Unix.

    Then recreate the tables, see Databases.

  • Content Services temporary folder

    Content Services needs the temporary folder of the application server, e.g. tomcat_install_dir/temp. If this folder is missing, adding content to Content Services from Backbase Portal Manager fails.

content:
1 Overview

1.1. Features

Backbase Portal offers a flexible way to manage web portals. Its architecture is based on a rich presentation layer and a loosely coupled Web-Oriented Architecture, and combines content and interaction in one solution. This is most evident with widgets, independent web applications that form the portal building blocks.

With Backbase Portal, end-users can personalize the online environments, the information and the applications they need. They can also add content, adjust visualisation preferences, and rearrange layouts.

The following figure shows the main modules of Backbase Portal:

Backbase Portal Client.  Backbase Portal Client shows the portal and enables interaction with the widgets. It communicates with Backbase Portal Foundation on the background to store the changes the end-user makes to the portal.

Backbase Portal Foundation.  Backbase Portal Foundation is the main engine that receives requests from clients, retrieves objects from the data store, sends responses back to the client and stores changes in the data store. It can serve multiple portal instances. For more information, see Portal.

Mashup Services.  Mashup Services delivers remote content to Backbase Portal widgets. For more information, see Mashup Services.

Content Services.  Content Services, an optional module, delivers local and remote content to Backbase Portal widgets. For more information, see Content Services.

1.1 Features

Backbase Portal Foundation

  • Multi-tenancy—Backbase Portal Foundation is capable of hosting multiple portals.

  • Data Storage—a single data store stores all portal instances (and their personalization data), Access Control List mappings, and (optionally) user credentials. This combination provides the foundation for a robust and flexible authorization and authentication mechanism.

  • Personalization—changes made by end-users to their personal Backbase Portal space are persisted from one application session to the next. The storage of personalizations is based on storing only the changes made to the original object. This method makes the data store very efficient.

  • Authentication—the use of Spring Security allows custom integration with a variety of authentication services. Backbase Portal relies on a single identity store to serve all portal instances, and can be configured to use either an external identity store or one that resides in the Backbase Portal data store. For more information, see Authentication and Authorization.

  • Authorization—support for both role-based and resource-based authorization delivers a robust and flexible access control mechanism. In both cases, authorization is governed by the combination of the authenticated end-user, permissions (as defined by the groups to which an end-user belongs), and the Backbase Portal object the end-user is trying to access. For more information, see Authentication and Authorization.

  • Persistence—uses Hibernate to persist objects, users, groups and preferences to several supported databases.

  • Portal and Page Management—a REST interface is available for managing Backbase Portal Foundation and and the portal instances it hosts. For more information, please refer to the REST API.

  • Widget Compatibility—Backbase Portal supports multiple widget formats, including Backbase Portal 4 gadgets.

  • Widget Library—out-of-the-box widgets are available for common end-user tasks, including a login page.

Content Services

  • Content Aggregation—data imported from remote content sources is stored in the Content Services content repository.

  • Installation—Content Services is delivered as a web application (WAR file) that can be deployed to one or more J2EE application servers.

  • Integration—CMIS (Content Management Interoperability Services) and WebDAV interfaces for working with content.

  • Administration—JMX (Java Management Extensions) interface for managing and monitoring the delivery service.

  • Scalability—support for clustering means that Content Services instances can be configured for a variety of backend technologies, including enterprise-level databases and JCR (Java Content Repository).

  • Performance—support for clustering means that Content Services instances can be configured for optimal delivery.

  • Failover—support for clustering means that requests can be routed to different Content Services instances if one instance is unavailable.

  • Importers—an optional Content Services component for importing external feeds.

  • Schedulers—for automated import of content.

  • Persistence—uses Hibernate to persist content to several supported databases.

Mashup Services

  • Proxy Service—proxying is needed to overcome the same-origin security policy that modern browsers apply to AJAX calls. To request resources (such as an XML file or application) from other intranet or Internet domains, Proxy Services proxies the request to the remote resource.

  • Transformation Service—provides filters and transformers that act on the request/response workflow.

  • Caching Service—improves performance by writing requested resources to cache. The default caching mechanism is implemented using Ehcache.

Top

1 Architecture

1.1. Distributed Environment
1.2. Release Management
1.3. Object Model
1.4. Publishing
1.4.1. What Gets Published?
1.4.2. Publishing Process
1.4.3. Security
1.5. Client-side and Server-side Rendering
1.6. Authentication and Authorization
1.7. Third-party Dependencies

Backbase Portal has a different setup on editorial environments or staging/live environments. The main difference is that editorial environments contain Backbase Portal Manager and the other environments don't. For more information on environments, see Release Management. Within one environment, the modules of Backbase Portal can run on different servers, see Distributed Environment.

Editorial Environments

The setup of Backbase Portal in an editorial environment is as follows:

Here follows a brief description of the items in the diagram.

  • Backbase Portal Foundation

    Backbase Portal Foundation performs the following tasks:

    • Authentication and Authorization

    • Server-side rendering

    • Persist changes to pages (and other objects) on the data store. For more information, see Object Model.

  • Mashup Services

    Mashup Services delivers remote content to Backbase Portal widgets. It acts as a proxy and allows to cache, filter and transform HTTP requests and responses. For more information, see Mashup Services.

  • Content Services

    Content Services is a content delivery platform. It can store content to its own database and can harvest remote content, for example from CMIS repositories. For more information, see Content Services.

  • Orchestrator

    The Orchestrator publishes database objects and content from Backbase Portal Foundation and Content Services. It performs the following tasks:

    • Lock published data to prevent further modifications.

    • Create, send, retrieve and unpack packages with published data.

    • Wait for approval of an authorized user before publishing.

    For more information, see Publishing.

  • Backbase Portal Manager

    Backbase Portal Manager is an application that allows the business user to manage and design pages in the portal and publish the changes to another environment, e.g. from editorial to staging. Backbase Portal Manager communicates with Backbase Portal to store changes and with Orchestrator to publish changes.

    For more information, see Backbase Portal Manager.

  • Templates

    Developers create templates that define how a page (and containers and widgets on the page) are rendered.

    For more information, see Customization.

  • Backbase Portal Client

    Backbase Portal Client performs the following tasks:

    • Client-side rendering

    • Handle interaction on the page and communicate changes to Backbase Portal Foundation.

  • REST client

    Backbase Portal Foundation has a REST interface and you can use any REST client to communicate with it. Data is conveyed via XML. For more information, see Communication.

Staging/Live Environments

The setup of Backbase Portal in staging or live environments is similar to the editorial environment, except that it does not include Backbase Portal Manager. Only the live environment is accessible for end-users.

1.1 Distributed Environment

Within one environment, the modules of Backbase Portal can run on different servers:

When you move a module to a different server, you need to take the following actions:

  • Backbase Portal Foundation

    Edit ice-config.properties on the classpath of the application server running Backbase Portal Foundation, or if Mashup Services runs stand-alone, on the classpath of the application server running Mashup Services. For more information, see Proxy Configuration.

  • Backbase Portal Foundation data store

    Edit the database configuration of Backbase Portal Foundation:

    • Apache Tomcat — the tomcat_install_dir/conf/context.xml file

    • WebSphere — the portalDS data source

    • JBoss — the {JBOSS-HOME}/server/default/deploy/database-type-ds.xml file

    For more information, see Application Servers.

  • Mashup Services (stand-alone)

    Edit the -DPORTALSERVER_PROXY_URL=mashup_services_url parameter either in the JAVA_OPTS environment variable or in the start up script of the application server running Backbase Portal Foundation. For more information, see Proxy Configuration.

  • Content Services

    1. Edit ice-config.properties on the classpath of the application server running Backbase Portal Foundation, or if Mashup Services runs stand-alone, on the classpath of the application server running Mashup Services.

    2. Edit contentservices-proxy.properties on the classpath of the application server running Backbase Portal Foundation.

    For more information, see Proxy Configuration.

  • Content Services database

    Edit the database configuration of Content Services:

    • Apache Tomcat — the tomcat_install_dir/conf/context.xml file

    • WebSphere — the content-ds, configuration-ds and resource-ds data sources

    • JBoss — the {JBOSS-HOME}/server/default/deploy/database-type-ds.xml file

    For more information, see Application Servers.

  • Content Services file system

    Edit the repository.configuration.fileLocation setting in the contentservices.properties file located on the classpath of the application server, e.g. the lib folder. You can set it to a shared folder located on a different machine. For more information, see Content Services Properties.

  • Orchestrator

    Edit orch-proxy.properties on the classpath of the application server running Backbase Portal Foundation. For more information, see Proxy Configuration.

  • Orchestrator database

    Edit the database configuration of Orchestrator:

    • Apache Tomcat — the tomcat_install_dir/conf/context.xml file

    • WebSphere — the orchestrator-ds data source

    • JBoss — the {JBOSS-HOME}/server/default/deploy/database-type-ds.xml file

    For more information, see Application Server.

Top

1.2 Release Management

Overview

Release management in Backbase Portal requires a DTAP route and a publishing route. The DTAP (development, test, acceptance and production) route handles the release of files. The publishing (editorial, staging, live) route handles the release of database objects.

Staging and live environments do not contain Backbase Portal Manager. For Backbase Portal Foundation, development environments are Maven projects. Test, accept and production environments are deployed WAR files.

DTAP Route

For Backbase Portal Foundation, files in the portal project are released via DTAP. Make sure to follow the best practice of using Bundles. You can either package a bundle and unpack that in other environment, or package the portal project in a WAR file and deploy the WAR to another environment.

For Mashup Services and Content Services, only an upgrade of the WAR file and configuration files are released via the DTAP route.

Publishing Route

Database objects of Backbase Portal Foundation and Content Services and the content repository of Content Services are released via publishing. Mashup Services is not part of publishing.

1.3 Object Model

This section explains the object model of Backbase Portal Foundation:

Backbase Portal Objects

These are the main objects in Backbase Portal:

  • Portals, pages, containers, widgets, and links

    These objects form the portal website, see Customization.

  • Users and groups

    Needed for Authentication and Authorization.

  • Templates

    Determine how pages, containers and widgets are rendered, see Customization.

  • Catalogs

    Logically group objects, e.g. a catalog with news widgets. They can contain any object that extends com.backbase.portal.foundation.domain.conceptual.Item.

These are the Java class names of the objects (see the Javadoc API):

Inheritance

The Backbase Portal object model uses inheritance extensively. When a business user places a widget on a page from the catalog, Backbase Portal Foundation creates a new widget that extends the widget in the catalog. The new widget inherits all elements from the extended widget.

Similarly, when an end-user personalizes an object, Backbase Portal Foundation extends the original object and applies the personalization. An example of a personalization is moving a widget to another location on the page.

Both in the case of extensions and personalizations, Backbase Portal only saves changes and not the inherited elements. This makes the Backbase Portal object model scalable and efficient.

Rights can either be set for a particulart object, or inherited as follows:

  • Abstract objects in the server catalog inherit the rights from Backbase Portal Foundation.

  • Abstract objects in a portal catalog inherit the rights from the portal.

  • Instantiated objects inherit the rights from their parent (either a portal, a page, or a container).

If any part of the rights of an object is set, all inherited rights are copied to the object.

State, Scope and Role

Each object has a state that combines two security aspects of the object:

  • Who can access this object?

    Backbase Portal supports multi-tenancy; you can manage multiple portals with one installation. Objects exist within either of three scopes and only administrators can access objects with the highest scope. This way, managers and users of a portal cannot access objects on another portal.

  • Is the object defined or instantiated?

    A defined object has no parent. An instantiated object has a parent, which is either a portal, a page or a container. This means that only an instantiated object is visible on the portal website.

    For example, when a widget is created, it has a defined state and no parent. When someone drags it on a page, Backbase Portal Foundation creates a new widget that extends the defined widget. The new widget will have an instantiated state and the page as parent.

Deleting Objects

Deleting an object in Backbase Portal has the following impact:

  • Children

    Some objects can have children (see Children above). Deletions in Backbase Portal always cascade, meaning that any children will also be deleted.

    For example, if you delete a page, its containers and widgets will also be deleted.

  • Inheritance

    Backbase Portal extends objects to make the object model efficient (see Inheritance above). Deletions in Backbase Portal always propagate, meaning that any objects that inherit form the deleted object will also be deleted. For example, if you delete a catalog widget, its widget instances will also be deleted.

  • Link references

    Deleting a link also deletes the page that the link refers to. This is the page with the uuid that corresponds to the link ItemRef property. If other links refer to the same page, the following applies:

    • If another link refers to the same page, the page is not deleted.

    • If a state link refers to the same page, the page is deleted and the state link is also deleted.

Only users with the ADMIN role can delete objects.

Note

Deletions in Backbase Portal cannot be undone.

Deleting Properties

It is possible to delete object properties by setting the MarkedForDeletion attribute to true in a PUT call. For more information, see propertyType.

1.4 Publishing

Backbase Portal supports publishing pages and content to different environments in a controlled manner. A typical setup has an editorial, staging and live environment:

  • Editorial environment

    Editors work with Backbase Portal Manager to make changes to pages and publish these changes (see Publishing Pages). The editorial environment requires Backbase Portal Manager and an Orchestrator in editorial mode.

  • Staging environment

    A business user previews the changes on the staging environment and can then approve or reject the changes via Backbase Portal Manager (running on the editorial environment). You can manage the whole publishing flow from Backbase Portal Manager, see Publishing Pages. Backbase Portal Manager should not run on the staging environment to prevent directly changing this environment. The staging environment requires an Orchestrator in staging/live mode to process publish packages from the Orchestrator in editorial mode.

  • Live environment

    End-users can access the portal on the live environment (e.g. via the Internet). Backbase Portal Manager should not run on the live environment to prevent directly changing this environment. The live environment requires an Orchestrator in staging/live mode to process publish packages from the Orchestrator in editorial mode.

Top

1.4.1 What Gets Published?

Backbase Portal can publish objects stored in the data store (see Object Model) and content stored in Content Services. It is not possible to publish files used by the portal (e.g. widget definitions, template files, configuration files).

For more information, see Which Route?.

Inheritance

Objects in Backbase Portal Foundation can inherit from other objects. If you publish an object that inherits from another object, Orchestrator also publishes the base object. For example, if you publish a widget derived from a catalog widget, Orchestrator also publishes the catalog widget.

This rule does not apply to objects in server scope, such as templates and items in the server catalog: these objects are never published. For a broader overview of inheritance in Backbase Portal see Object Model.

Children

Orchestrator publishes the requested objects and their parents. Publishing a container tab, for example, automatically causes the parent page to be published as well. Likewise, publishing a link will cause all its parents up to the root link to be published. The pages referenced by the parent links, however, are not published.

For example, a page is part of a two-level navigation tree. When you publish the page, Orchestrator publishes both the page, its corresponding link as well as the parent link. The page associated with the parent link, however, is not published. The parent link on the staging environment will be a header link.

This way, the navigation tree stays consistent even if it is only partially published, but prevents pages from being published unless explicitly requested.

Unpublishing an object causes its children to be unpublished as well.

Top

1.4.2 Publishing Process

Orchestrator and the Publishing Chain

The Orchestrator module is in charge of the publishing process. It must be present on all environments alongside Backbase Portal Foundation, but uses an independent H2 Database Engine. The Orchestrator locks data, sends and retrieves packages, manages approval and unlocks data. These actions are part of the publishing chain:

  1. An editor modifies a page in the portal or content in Content Services. Examples of changes are: adding a widget, changing the position of a widget, changing the layout of a page, editing a text.

  2. The editor publishes the changes in Backbase Portal Manager.

  3. The editorial Orchestrator locks the data (making further modifications impossible), creates a package (a ZIP-based archive), and sends it to a staging environment.

  4. The Orchestrator in the staging environment unpacks the data and publishes them to Backbase Portal Foundation and Content Services.

  5. An approver previews the portal on the staging environment.

    • If the approver rejects the changes:

      1. The editorial Orchestrator unlocks the data for further modifications.

    • If the approver accepts the changes:

      1. The editorial Orchestrator sends the package to the live environment.

      2. The Orchestrator in the live environment unpacks the package and publishes it to the outside world.

      3. The editorial Orchestrator unlocks the data.

Backbase Portal ships with these publishing chains. Currently, other publishing chains are not supported.

  • Direct

    This chain has no staging environment, so a published page is immediately visible on the live environment.

  • Approval on Package

    The approver can approve or reject the package. A rejected package will not continue to the live environment.

  • Approval on Pages

    The approver needs to approve every single page in the package. If he rejects one or more pages, the package will not continue to the live environment.

For more information about configuring the publishing chain, see Publishing.

Publishing Within an Environment

For testing and demo purposes, Backbase Portal can also publish within one environment. In this scenario, publishing takes place across different portals instead of environments. This allows the use of publishing functionality without installing Backbase Portal on multiple machines. Content is not published in this scenario. This means that the editorial portal uses the same content in Content Services as the live portal.

For example, Orchestrator publishes from the editorial portal to the staging portal and from there to the live portal:

Publishing within an environment is an optional feature configurable in the Orchestrator configuration file, see Publishing.

Unpublishing

Items published to non-editorial environments are locked and cannot be deleted. In order to delete them, you first need to unpublish them.

Unpublishing means removing pages from a portal. On staging or live environments, unpublished pages are removed from the local data store. On editorial environments, pages continue to exist in the data store of the editorial environment so that they are still available for future publishing, if needed.

Before a page can be unpublished, it needs to have completed the publishing chain. For example, if a page follows the Approval on Pages publishing chain explained below, it cannot be unpublished until it has reached the live environment, or until an approver has rejected the publishing request.

Warning

When unpublishing a page, make sure you select the correct publishing chain. For example, if a page was published to a live environment through a Approval on Pages publishing chain, unpublishing it through a Direct publishing chain will return an error.

Republishing

If you published some pages and subsequently modified them in the editorial environment, you can republish those pages with one button click in Backbase Portal Manager. This republishes all changed pages that have already been published to other environments.

The links and CMIS content related to the pages are republished as well. Republishing has the same effect as manually selecting the individual pages, but can save time and is less error-prone.

1.4.3 Security

Orchestrator has two roles that you can map to roles in Backbase Portal Foundation:

  • approver

    Users who approve publish requests need this role. In addition, they cannot approve their own publish requests.

  • publisher

    Users who submit publish requests need this role.

In the configuration, you can assign Backbase Portal Foundation groups to these roles. For example, you can create an approver group in Backbase Portal Foundation, assign users to this group and then add the group to the approver role in the configuration of Orchestrator, see Publishing. The users in the approver group now have permission to approve publish requests in Backbase Portal Manager.
