The global-constants.js file contains constants that apply to Backbase Portal Manager. The file is located in the target/your_project/static/conf in your portal project.

If you want to edit the file, you have to copy it from the target folder to the src folder. First create the folder src/main/webapp/static/conf in your portal project. Then copy the file from target/your_project/static/conf to the created folder.

1.1. Distributed Environment
1.2. Release Management
1.3. Object Model

1.4.1. What Gets Published?

1.7. Third-party Dependencies

Backbase Portal has a different setup on editorial environments or staging/live environments. The main difference is that editorial environments contain Backbase Portal Manager and the other environments don't. For more information on environments, see Release Management. Within one environment, the modules of Backbase Portal can run on different servers, see Distributed Environment.

Editorial Environments

The setup of Backbase Portal in an editorial environment is as follows:

Here follows a brief description of the items in the diagram.

  • Backbase Portal Foundation

    Backbase Portal Foundation performs the following tasks:

    • Authentication and Authorization

    • Server-side rendering

    • Persist changes to pages (and other objects) on the data store. For more information, see Object Model.

  • Mashup Services

    Mashup Services delivers remote content to Backbase Portal widgets. It acts as a proxy and allows to cache, filter and transform HTTP requests and responses. For more information, see Mashup Services.

  • Content Services

    Content Services is a content delivery platform. It can store content to its own database and can harvest remote content, for example from CMIS repositories. For more information, see Content Services.

  • Orchestrator

    The Orchestrator publishes database objects and content from Backbase Portal Foundation and Content Services. It performs the following tasks:

    • Lock published data to prevent further modifications.

    • Create, send, retrieve and unpack packages with published data.

    • Wait for approval of an authorized user before publishing.

    For more information, see Publishing.

  • Backbase Portal Manager

    Backbase Portal Manager is an application that allows the business user to manage and design pages in the portal and publish the changes to another environment, e.g. from editorial to staging. Backbase Portal Manager communicates with Backbase Portal to store changes and with Orchestrator to publish changes.

    For more information, see Backbase Portal Manager.

  • Templates

    Developers create templates that define how a page (and containers and widgets on the page) are rendered.

    For more information, see Customization.

  • Backbase Portal Client

    Backbase Portal Client performs the following tasks:

    • Client-side rendering

    • Handle interaction on the page and communicate changes to Backbase Portal Foundation.

  • REST client

    Backbase Portal Foundation has a REST interface and you can use any REST client to communicate with it. Data is conveyed via XML. For more information, see Communication.

Staging/Live Environments

The setup of Backbase Portal in staging or live environments is similar to the editorial environment, except that it does not include Backbase Portal Manager. Only the live environment is accessible for end-users.

1.1 Distributed Environment

Within one environment, the modules of Backbase Portal can run on different servers:

When you move a module to a different server, you need to take the following actions:

  • Backbase Portal Foundation

    Edit ice-config.properties on the classpath of the application server running Backbase Portal Foundation, or if Mashup Services runs stand-alone, on the classpath of the application server running Mashup Services. For more information, see Proxy Configuration.

  • Backbase Portal Foundation data store

    Edit the database configuration of Backbase Portal Foundation:

    • Apache Tomcat — the tomcat_install_dir/conf/context.xml file

    • WebSphere — the portalDS data source

    • JBoss — the {JBOSS-HOME}/server/default/deploy/database-type-ds.xml file

    For more information, see Application Servers.

  • Mashup Services (stand-alone)

    Edit the -DPORTALSERVER_PROXY_URL=mashup_services_url parameter either in the JAVA_OPTS environment variable or in the start up script of the application server running Backbase Portal Foundation. For more information, see Proxy Configuration.

  • Content Services

    1. Edit ice-config.properties on the classpath of the application server running Backbase Portal Foundation, or if Mashup Services runs stand-alone, on the classpath of the application server running Mashup Services.

    2. Edit contentservices-proxy.properties on the classpath of the application server running Backbase Portal Foundation.

    For more information, see Proxy Configuration.

  • Content Services database

    Edit the database configuration of Content Services:

    • Apache Tomcat — the tomcat_install_dir/conf/context.xml file

    • WebSphere — the content-ds, configuration-ds and resource-ds data sources

    • JBoss — the {JBOSS-HOME}/server/default/deploy/database-type-ds.xml file

    For more information, see Application Servers.

  • Content Services file system

    Edit the repository.configuration.fileLocation setting in the contentservices.properties file located on the classpath of the application server, e.g. the lib folder. You can set it to a shared folder located on a different machine. For more information, see Content Services Properties.

  • Orchestrator

    Edit orch-proxy.properties on the classpath of the application server running Backbase Portal Foundation. For more information, see Proxy Configuration.

1.2 Release Management

Overview

Release management in Backbase Portal requires a DTAP route and a publishing route. The DTAP (development, test, acceptance and production) route handles the release of files. The publishing (editorial, staging, live) route handles the release of database objects.

Staging and live environments do not contain Backbase Portal Manager. For Backbase Portal Foundation, development environments are Maven projects. Test, accept and production environments are deployed WAR files.

DTAP Route

For Backbase Portal Foundation, files in the portal project are released via DTAP. Make sure to follow the best practice of using Bundles. You can either package a bundle and unpack that in other environment, or package the portal project in a WAR file and deploy the WAR to another environment.

For Mashup Services and Content Services, only an upgrade of the WAR file and configuration files are released via the DTAP route.

Publishing Route

Database objects of Backbase Portal Foundation and Content Services and the content repository of Content Services are released via publishing. Mashup Services is not part of publishing.

Inheritance

The Backbase Portal object model uses inheritance extensively. When a business user places a widget on a page from the catalog, Backbase Portal Foundation creates a new widget that extends the widget in the catalog. The new widget inherits all elements from the extended widget.

Similarly, when an end-user personalizes an object, Backbase Portal Foundation extends the original object and applies the personalization. An example of a personalization is moving a widget to another location on the page.

Both in the case of extensions and personalizations, Backbase Portal only saves changes and not the inherited elements. This makes the Backbase Portal object model scalable and efficient.

Rights can either be set for a particulart object, or inherited as follows:

  • Abstract objects in the server catalog inherit the rights from Backbase Portal Foundation.

  • Abstract objects in a portal catalog inherit the rights from the portal.

  • Instantiated objects inherit the rights from their parent (either a portal, a page, or a container).

If any part of the rights of an object is set, all inherited rights are copied to the object.

State, Scope and Role

Each object has a state that combines two security aspects of the object:

  • Who can access this object?

    Backbase Portal supports multi-tenancy; you can manage multiple portals with one installation. Objects exist within either of three scopes and only administrators can access objects with the highest scope. This way, managers and users of a portal cannot access objects on another portal.

  • Is the object defined or instantiated?

    A defined object has no parent. An instantiated object has a parent, which is either a portal, a page or a container. This means that only an instantiated object is visible on the portal website.

    For example, when a widget is created, it has a defined state and no parent. When someone drags it on a page, Backbase Portal Foundation creates a new widget that extends the defined widget. The new widget will have an instantiated state and the page as parent.

Deleting Objects

Deleting an object in Backbase Portal has the following impact:

  • Children

    Some objects can have children (see Children above). Deletions in Backbase Portal always cascade, meaning that any children will also be deleted.

    For example, if you delete a page, its containers and widgets will also be deleted.

  • Inheritance

    Backbase Portal extends objects to make the object model efficient (see Inheritance above). Deletions in Backbase Portal always propagate, meaning that any objects that inherit form the deleted object will also be deleted. For example, if you delete a catalog widget, its widget instances will also be deleted.

  • Link references

    Deleting a link also deletes the page that the link refers to. This is the page with the uuid that corresponds to the link ItemRef property. If other links refer to the same page, the following applies:

    • If another link refers to the same page, the page is not deleted.

    • If a state link refers to the same page, the page is deleted and the state link is also deleted.

Only users with the ADMIN role can delete objects.

Note

Deletions in Backbase Portal cannot be undone.

Deleting Properties

It is possible to delete object properties by setting the MarkedForDeletion attribute to true in a PUT call. For more information, see propertyType.

1.4 Publishing

Backbase Portal supports publishing pages and content to different environments in a controlled manner. A typical setup has an editorial, staging and live environment:

  • Editorial environment

    Editors work with Backbase Portal Manager to make changes to pages and publish these changes (see Publishing Pages). The editorial environment requires Backbase Portal Manager and an Orchestrator in editorial mode.

  • Staging environment

    A business user previews the changes on the staging environment and can then approve or reject the changes via Backbase Portal Manager (running on the editorial environment). You can manage the whole publishing flow from Backbase Portal Manager, see Publishing Pages. Backbase Portal Manager should not run on the staging environment to prevent directly changing this environment. The staging environment requires an Orchestrator in staging/live mode to process publish packages from the Orchestrator in editorial mode.

  • Live environment

    End-users can access the portal on the live environment (e.g. via the Internet). Backbase Portal Manager should not run on the live environment to prevent directly changing this environment. The live environment requires an Orchestrator in staging/live mode to process publish packages from the Orchestrator in editorial mode.

Top

1.4.1 What Gets Published?

Backbase Portal can publish objects stored in the data store (see Object Model) and content stored in Content Services. It is not possible to publish files used by the portal (e.g. widget definitions, template files, configuration files).

For more information, see Which Route?.

Inheritance

Objects in Backbase Portal Foundation can inherit from other objects. If you publish an object that inherits from another object, Orchestrator also publishes the base object. For example, if you publish a widget derived from a catalog widget, Orchestrator also publishes the catalog widget.

This rule does not apply to objects in server scope, such as templates and items in the server catalog: these objects are never published. For a broader overview of inheritance in Backbase Portal see Object Model.

Children

Orchestrator publishes the requested objects and their parents. Publishing a container tab, for example, automatically causes the parent page to be published as well. Likewise, publishing a link will cause all its parents up to the root link to be published. The pages referenced by the parent links, however, are not published.

For example, a page is part of a two-level navigation tree. When you publish the page, Orchestrator publishes both the page, its corresponding link as well as the parent link. The page associated with the parent link, however, is not published. The parent link on the staging environment will be a header link.

This way, the navigation tree stays consistent even if it is only partially published, but prevents pages from being published unless explicitly requested.

Unpublishing an object causes its children to be unpublished as well.

1.4.2 Publishing Process

Orchestrator and the Publishing Chain

The Orchestrator module is in charge of the publishing process. It must be present on all environments alongside Backbase Portal Foundation, but uses an independent H2 Database Engine. The Orchestrator locks data, sends and retrieves packages, manages approval and unlocks data. These actions are part of the publishing chain:

  1. An editor modifies a page in the portal or content in Content Services. Examples of changes are: adding a widget, changing the position of a widget, changing the layout of a page, editing a text.

  2. The editor publishes the changes in Backbase Portal Manager.

  3. The editorial Orchestrator locks the data (making further modifications impossible), creates a package (a ZIP-based archive), and sends it to a staging environment.

  4. The Orchestrator in the staging environment unpacks the data and publishes them to Backbase Portal Foundation and Content Services.

  5. An approver previews the portal on the staging environment.

    • If the approver rejects the changes:

      1. The editorial Orchestrator unlocks the data for further modifications.

    • If the approver accepts the changes:

      1. The editorial Orchestrator sends the package to the live environment.

      2. The Orchestrator in the live environment unpacks the package and publishes it to the outside world.

      3. The editorial Orchestrator unlocks the data.

Backbase Portal ships with these publishing chains. Currently, other publishing chains are not supported.

  • Direct

    This chain has no staging environment, so a published page is immediately visible on the live environment.

  • Approval on Package

    The approver can approve or reject the package. A rejected package will not continue to the live environment.

  • Approval on Pages

    The approver needs to approve every single page in the package. If he rejects one or more pages, the package will not continue to the live environment.

For more information about configuring the publishing chain, see Publishing.

Publishing Within an Environment

For testing and demo purposes, Backbase Portal can also publish within one environment. In this scenario, publishing takes place across different portals instead of environments. This allows the use of publishing functionality without installing Backbase Portal on multiple machines. Content is not published in this scenario. This means that the editorial portal uses the same content in Content Services as the live portal.

For example, Orchestrator publishes from the editorial portal to the staging portal and from there to the live portal:

Publishing within an environment is an optional feature configurable in the Orchestrator configuration file, see Publishing.

Unpublishing

Items published to non-editorial environments are locked and cannot be deleted. In order to delete them, you first need to unpublish them.

Unpublishing means removing pages from a portal. On staging or live environments, unpublished pages are removed from the local data store. On editorial environments, pages continue to exist in the data store of the editorial environment so that they are still available for future publishing, if needed.

Before a page can be unpublished, it needs to have completed the publishing chain. For example, if a page follows the Approval on Pages publishing chain explained below, it cannot be unpublished until it has reached the live environment, or until an approver has rejected the publishing request.

Warning

When unpublishing a page, make sure you select the correct publishing chain. For example, if a page was published to a live environment through a Approval on Pages publishing chain, unpublishing it through a Direct publishing chain will return an error.

Republishing

If you published some pages and subsequently modified them in the editorial environment, you can republish those pages with one button click in Backbase Portal Manager. This republishes all changed pages that have already been published to other environments.

The links and CMIS content related to the pages are republished as well. Republishing has the same effect as manually selecting the individual pages, but can save time and is less error-prone.

1.4.3 Security

Orchestrator has two roles that you can map to roles in Backbase Portal Foundation:

  • approver

    Users who approve publish requests need this role. In addition, they cannot approve their own publish requests.

  • publisher

    Users who submit publish requests need this role.

In the configuration, you can assign Backbase Portal Foundation groups to these roles. For example, you can create an approver group in Backbase Portal Foundation, assign users to this group and then add the group to the approver role in the configuration of Orchestrator, see Publishing. The users in the approver group now have permission to approve publish requests in Backbase Portal Manager.

1.5 Client-side and Server-side Rendering

Model-view-controller Pattern

Backbase Portal is based on the Spring MVC framework and implements the model-view-controller pattern. Objects belonging to the Backbase Portal Object Model are stored in the data store. Rendering of the model happens either client-side or server-side: in the former case the controller is JavaScript code (that is part of Backbase Portal Client), in the latter JSP templates.

The flow chart below shows the model-content-view pattern implementation in Backbase Portal:

Note

Green arrows show server-side rendering

Red arrows show client-side rendering

Client-side Rendering

If an object is client-side rendered, Backbase Portal Client renders the HTML code based on the model included in the server response. Backbase Portal Client handles interaction, e.g. when the user moves a widget. It sends changes to the model back to the server as XML through the REST API.

For more information, see How to Use Client-side and Server-side Rendering.

Server-side Rendering

If a client requests a server-side rendered object, the server renders the HTML according to the JavaServer Pages template of the object. Backbase Portal Client handles interaction, e.g. when the user moves a widget. It sends changes to the model back to the server as XML through the REST API.

For more information, see How to Use Client-side and Server-side Rendering.

Relative Merits

Each rendering mode has advantages over the other. See the following list for an overview:

  • Cost: the computing and memory resources needed to render objects on the server are limited and come at a cost. Implementing client-side rendering reduces the pressure on the available servers.

  • Bandwidth usage: in client-side rendering only the model is exchanged - in XML format - with minimal bandwidth usage. Serving the full HTML code is much more resource-consuming.

  • Required skills: client-side rendering is based on JavaScript, while server-side rendering uses JavaServer Pages. The skills available in-house play a role in balancing between the two modes.

  • Rendering speed: objects are generally rendered faster client-side. In client-side rendering, the server and client only exchange the model XML code instead of the HTML for the whole page, so changes are rendered quickly.

  • Speed at first load: perhaps contradicting the previous point, objects like pages and containers are loaded faster server-side the first time. Client-side, objects need to load all related resources (like JavaScript files) before they can be rendered, providing a slower user experience.

  • Search Engine Optimization (SEO): client-side scripting often scores badly in search rankings. If SEO is a requirement, server-side rendering is the better alternative.

  • Accessibility: dynamic content is often not accessible by users with disabilities. If accessibility is a requirement, developers should consider server-side rendering.

  • Security: client-side rendering tends to be more secure because the attack surface is limited to the REST API, while server-side rendering also needs the HTML API.

  • Simplicity: the model-view-controller pattern for client-side rendering only involves one controller - the JavaScript code. Server-side rendering also needs JavaServer Pages, and is conceptually more complex.

Users

Users can be visitors to the portal website or administrators and managers of the portal. The permissions of the user are determined by the groups assigned to the user.

Backbase Portal supports authenticated and anonymous (unauthenticated) users.

1 Overview

Content Services is a content delivery platform provided as a Backbase Portal optional module. It provides repository capabilities and relies on a library of Importers to harvest content from sources like CMIS repositories or RSS and Atom feeds.

The following figure shows the elements composing Content Services:

Repositories

Content Services implements the CMIS Standard and relies on three repositories to manage content and configuration files:

  • contentRepository stores content used by Backbase Portal, like images, text, and content harvested from remote sources. One can navigate this repository from the Content Browser in Backbase Portal Manager. For more information, see Architecture.

  • configurationRepository stores configuration files for Importers.

  • resourcesRepository stores Backbase Portal resources.

Interfaces

Content Services is accessible via the following interfaces:

  • CMIS interface: enables interaction with any of the three repositories (contentRepository, configurationRepository, and resourcesRepository) at a very low level, for example down to metadata. You can establish connections using a CMIS client such as CMIS Workbench, via Paging, Filtering and Sorting URL modifiers, or by implementing a Mashup Services custom data provider.

  • WebDAV interface: allows to manipulate objects and folders in Content Services repositories. WebDAV clients such as BitKinex and WebDAV-enabled applications such as Adobe Dreamweaver CS5 provide both file system and editing support. For file system operations alone, a WebDAV-enabled file manager like Microsoft Windows Explorer is sufficient. For more information, see Mounting Repositories.

  • JMX interface: manages and monitors the content delivery service and is useful to configure and administer the Content Services server. For more information, see JMX Interface.

2.2 Importers

Content Services uses importers coupled with Importer Jobs to retrieve external content and store it in a repository. Default importers exist for RSS and Atom feeds, and for remote CMIS repositories.

Importer configurations are dynamic: you can add, edit or remove configurations at runtime. Each external source needs a separate configuration file: manipulate configuration files with a WebDAV client like BitKinex. For more information, see Enabling WebDAV.

Warning

Do not edit configurations directly on the host file system, but use a WebDAV or CMIS client instead. The repository is not able to monitor these revisions and the repository metadata can become corrupted.

Importer configurations for RSS and Atom feeds reside in the importers/feed folder of configurationRepository, for CMIS in the importers/cmis folder. For more information, see Feeds.

RSS and Atom Feeds Configuration

This is an example of an RSS feed configuration:

id=myFeedImporter
group=feedgroup
description=some_description
targetRepositoryId=contentRepository
targetFolderPath=/myfeeds
remoteLocation=http://www.host.com/feeds/rss/general.rss
defaultEncoding=utf-8

2.3 Importer Jobs

Content Services uses Quartz Scheduler to automatically run importer jobs.

Importer job configurations reside in the scheduler/jobs folder of configurationRepository. You can set the location of additional configurations in the the <value> section of the META-INF/spring/bb-contentservices-repository-importer-scheduler.xml file located in WEB-INF/lib/repository-5.2.1.0.jar in the unpacked WAR file of Content Services. The syntax is as follows: 

<list>
    <value>/scheduler/jobs</value>
    <value>another_location</value>
</list>
Enabling Quartz Scheduler

Content Services uses Quartz to schedule Importer Jobs. The scheduler is disabled by default: to activate it, open the contentservices.properties file located on the classpath, e.g. in the lib folder of the application server, or create the file if it doesn't exist yet. Add the following line to the file:

repository.scheduler.enabled=true
Quartz Configuration

You can configure Quartz in the quartz.properties file located in WEB-INF/lib/repository-5.2.1.0.jar in the unpacked WAR file of Content Services. For more information, please refer to Quartz Configuration Reference.

This is an example of the Quartz configuration file:

org.quartz.scheduler.instanceName=ContentServicesImporterScheduler
org.quartz.scheduler.instanceId=AUTO
org.quartz.scheduler.skipUpdateCheck=true

org.quartz.threadPool.class=org.quartz.simpl.SimpleThreadPool
org.quartz.threadPool.threadCount=3
org.quartz.threadPool.threadPriority=5

org.quartz.jobStore.misfireThreshold=60000
org.quartz.jobStore.class=org.quartz.simpl.RAMJobStore
Importer Job Configurations

This is an example of an importer job configuration:

#this job runs the feedgroup importer configurations every 4 seconds
id=myJob1
jobGroup=feedgroup
cron=0/4 * * * * ?

The following table shows the keys you can use in an importer job configuration:

Table 2.4. Job Configuration Properties

Property

Description

id

A unique identifier for the job.

jobGroup

This property maps a job to a group of importers identified by the importer group property. The job runs all the importers in the group.

cron

Defines the interval at which an import job is triggered. For details of Cron syntax, please refer to Quartz 1.x Tutorials: crontrigger and Cron Expressions.

2.4 Enabling WebDAV

Web-based Distributed Authoring and Versioning (WebDAV) is a set of methods based on the Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) that facilitates collaboration between users in editing and managing documents and files stored on World Wide Web servers. For more information, please refer to WebDAV Resources.

WebDAV access is disabled by default. To enable it, open the contentservices.properties file in your application server lib folder and add the following line:

repository.webdav.enabled=true

Restart the application server after editing the file.

You can access Content Services repositories with a WebDAV client like BitKinex, by mapping a network drive to the repository URL under Microsoft Windows Explorer, or by mounting the URL to your file system under Linux. For more information, see Mounting Repositories.

2.5 Cache-Control Header Configuration

Browser Caches

A browser cache stores representations of resources requested in the past, like HTML pages, images and other files on the client machine. In case of another request for the same URL, the client can use the cached representation instead of fetching it again from the server. Browser caches are mainly used for these purposes:

  • Reducing latency: it takes the browser less time to display cached representations since requests are satisfied locally and not by the web server, and this makes web-pages more responsive.

  • Reducing network traffic: with browser caches, a server needs to send less representations to the clients and needs less bandwidth. This translates into savings not only for the server operator, but for the client as well: think of mobile subscriptions where Internet access is billed per megabyte.

Browser caches also have downsides: cached content can become out-of-date and caching can distort access statistics, hurting business models dependent on view counts.

Server administrators can control caches through HTML <meta> tags and HTTP headers. The following section explains how HTTP cache-control headers are set by Content Services.

HTTP Cache-Control Headers

Whenever Content Services sends a representation in response to a client request, it attaches HTTP headers specifying, among other things, the caching configuration for the representation. The image below shows a simple HTTP session:

The cache-control header specifies where a representation can be cached and for how long. Its syntax is as follows:

Cache-control: cache-directive

The cache-directive is anything valid according to the W3 HTTP 1.1 Specification. Commonly used directives are public, private, and max-age.

Content Services Configuration

The pre-defined configuration sets max-age for the image MIME type to five minutes (300 seconds), and 0 seconds for all other MIME types: in other words, images are cached for five minutes, and non-image files are not cached. One can override the default configurations and set exceptions for individual MIME types (like text, image or application) and sub-types (like text/html, image/jpeg and application/x-javascript).

Follow the steps below to override the pre-defined settings:

  1. Set a default configuration in the properties file

    Open the contentservices.properties file located on the classpath, e.g. in the lib folder of the application server, or create the file if it doesn't exist yet. Enter the contentservices.cache-control.default key in the file body, which sets the caching default configuration, while all the ensuing keys are exceptions to this configuration.

    The default key accepts any directive valid according to the W3 HTTP 1.1 Specification. For example, the following default key caches all representations for ten minutes (600 seconds):

    contentservices.cache-control.default=public; max-age=600

  2. List the MIME types and sub-types overriding the default configuration.

    Every MIME type or sub-type requires two keys: the first one to identify the MIME type, and the second one to specify the cache directive. The keys should conform to the following syntax:

    contentservices.cache-control.<index>.mime-type
contentservices.cache-control.<index>.cache-value

    <index> is an integer sequence number identifying the mime-type and the cache-value. The sequence number must be the same for both keys, is zero-based and must increment in steps of 1.

    MIME sub-types like text/html, application/x-java-applet or image/jpeg are more specific and match before MIME types like text, application and image.

    The following example sets a default configuration for the cache-control headers and adds exceptions for images and HTML files:

    contentservices.cache-control.default=public; max-age=600
contentservices.cache-control.0.mime-type=image
contentservices.cache-control.0.cache-value=public; max-age=600
contentservices.cache-control.1.mime-type=image/jpeg
contentservices.cache-control.1.cache-value=public; max-age=300
contentservices.cache-control.2.mime-type=text/html
contentservices.cache-control.2.cache-value=public; max-age=900

    Overrides the default settings and caches all representations for 10 minutes.

    Images may be cached by any cache (public) for a maximum of ten minutes (max-age=600).

    JPEG images may be cached by any cache (public) for a maximum of five minutes (max-age=300). Note that this directive is more specific than the one above and matches first.

    HTML files may be cached by any cache (public) for a maximum of fifteen minutes (max-age=900).

    The Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA) keeps an updated list of MIME content types and sub-types on its website.

  3. Restart the application server to apply the configuration changes.

Top

2.6 JMX Interface

JMX Integration

JMX (Java Management Extensions) is a Java technology that uses MBeans to manage and monitor applications running on a Java Virtual Machine. Within Content Services, it can monitor, for instance, the local application server, repository database or cache. The core class in Spring JMX framework is the MBeanExporter. This class is responsible for taking Spring beans and registering them with a JMX MBeanServer. Content Services ships with a logback MBean, a Ehcache Mbean, and a Hibernate Mbean. More MBeans can be added through annotations or by reconfiguring the <context:mbean-export/> element. For more information, please refer to Spring JMX Reference.

Java Management Extensions is configured to start an auto-scanning JMX exporter and connect to an existing MBean server. If none is found, Java Management Extensions can start one. The Java Management Extensions server can in turn interface with applications like HP OpenView, IBM Tivoli, JConsole, Nagios or others.

Available Mbeans

The following Mbeans are currently available:

  • The Ehcache Mbean exposes configuration parameters like timeToLiveSeconds, timeToIdleSeconds, maxEntriesLocalHeap, maxEntriesLocalDisk and memory-store eviction policy. The configuration can be changed dynamically with, for example, JConsole. This Mbean also gives access to statistics about cache hits and misses, cache usage and memory management.

  • The Hibernate Mbean exposes statistics about, for instance, the number of open and closed sessions, cache usage, CRUD operations and executed queries.

  • The logback Mbean allows configuration of logback via JMX. It lets you reconfigure logback from the default configuration file, a designated file or a URL, list loggers and modify logger levels.

Specifying the MBean Server

If no server is specified, the MBeanExporter tries to automatically detect a running MBeanServer. This works in environments with only one MBeanServer instance, but when multiple instances exist, you need to specify the instance with MBeanServer agentId.

To do so, edit the bb-contentservices-jmx.xml file in the contentservices/WEB-INF/classes/META-INF/spring folder within the unpacked contentservices-webapp-5.2.1.0.war file and modify it as follows:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="no"?>
<beans>
    <bean id="mbeanServer" class="org.springframework.jmx.support.MBeanServerFactoryBean">
        <!-- indicate to first look for a server -->
        <property name="locateExistingServerIfPossible" value="true"/>
        <!-- search for the MBeanServer instance with the given agentId -->
        <property name="agentId" value="<MBeanServer instance agentId"/>
    </bean>
    ...
</beans>

If the MBeanServer has a dynamic or unknown agentId that is retrieved through lookup methods, use factory-method as follows:

<beans>
    <bean id="exporter" class="org.springframework.jmx.export.MBeanExporter">
        <property name="server">
            <!-- Custom MBeanServerLocator -->
            <bean class="platform.package.MBeanServerLocator" factory-method="locateMBeanServer"/>
        </property>
    </bean>
    ...
</beans>

For more information, please refer to Spring JMX reference.

3 CMIS Object Model

3.1. CMIS Query
3.2. Paging, Filtering and Sorting
3.3. Query Comparison Matrix
3.4. CMIS Services Comparison

The CMIS object model represents entities in CMIS repositories. The Content Services implementation of the CMIS model consists of the cmis:document and cmis:folder basic object types, to which repository objects belong. The two other standard object types, cmis:relationship and cmis:policy, are not implemented, see picture below. For an overview of the CMIS services implemented in Content Services, see CMIS Services Comparison. To access CMIS repositories, see CMIS Workbench.

CMIS object types have a queryable and a queryName attribute: queryable determines whether an object type should be queried, and queryName is used to identify the object type in the FROM clause of a SELECT statement. Similarly, object properties have a queryable attribute that is used in WHERE clauses.

Note

Content Services currently does not support the standard includedInSuperType attribute.

Each object type has a list of attributes and properties specific to that particular type: these are spelled out in the CMIS specification, which also details how to extend the basic object types and create new ones. For a more detailed explanation of the individual basic object types, please see the CMIS Standard.

Object Types

These are the object types in Content Services:

  • cmis:document

    The cmis:document object type represents pieces of content in the repository, like images, text or CSS files. Document objects may have content streams, i.e. files, associated with them, or may not. For example, the Content Services bb:link custom object type extends cmis:document and contains no content streams. If present, content streams are associated to a MIME type and can have Renditions.

  • cmis:folder

    cmis:folder objects are folders in the repository and contain cmis:document objects. They can only have one parent folder and can contain multiple cmis:document objects. Folder objects may have Renditions.

    Note

    Content Services currently does not support the cmis:allowedChildObjectTypeIds attribute in the cmis:folder object type.

  • bb:link

    Stores hyperlinks. This object type has no content stream. It extends cmis:document and adds the following properties:

    • bb:url: the link URL

    • bb:title: the link text

  • bb:richtext

    Stores rich text content for the Rich Text Editor widget. It extends cmis:document and adds the following properties:

    • bb:title: the title of the text item

    • bb:subTitle: the subtitle of the text item

    • bb:description: the description of the text item

  • bb:image

    Stores images. It extends cmis:document and adds the following properties:

    • bb:altText: the alternative text in case the image cannot be displayed

    • bb:height: the image height in pixels

    • bb:width: the image width in pixels

    • bb:tag: a comma-separated list of tags with meta data

    • bb:title: the title of the image

    • bb:lastPublishedDate: the last publishing date

    • bb:subTitle: the subtitle of the image

    • bb:description: the description of the image

3.1 CMIS Query

Content Services implements a subset of the query language specified in the CMIS Standard, itself an implementation of the SQL-92 standard. For a list of supported CMIS features, see Query Comparison Matrix. This topic describes the CMIS query language as used in Content Services. You can execute CMIS queries from a CMIS client like CMIS Workbench.

Query structure

CMIS-compliant repositories map all queryable object types to so-called virtual tables where virtual columns are the queryable properties and rows are the objects. CMIS queries are executed on the virtual tables.

According to the SQL-92 specification, a SELECT statement must precede a FROM clause and, optionally, WHERE, GROUP BY, HAVING or ORDER BY clauses.

Content Services however only implements the FROM, WHERE and ORDER BY clauses and does not implement the GROUP BY and HAVING clauses.

  • SELECT

    The SELECT statement specifies the columns to retrieve from the table specified in the FROM clause. Contrary to the CMIS specification, you can only use an asterisk (*, meaning all columns) in the SELECT statement in Content Services.

  • FROM

    The FROM clause specifies the virtual table, i.e. the object type.

  • WHERE

    The WHERE clause is optional and filters the results to match a condition.

    Note

    Content Services does not support the following operators in the WHERE conditional clause: NULL, quantified comparison operators (ANY, ALL and SOME) and BETWEEN.

    These are the supported operators:

    Table 3.1. CMIS Query Operators

    Operator

    Description

    =

    Equal to

    <>

    Unequal to

    <

    Less than

    >

    Greater than

    <=

    Less than or equal to

    >=

    Greater than or equal to

    IN

    Matches the value against a specified value list. For example, the following statement returns objects with the Backbase Object Types:

    SELECT * FROM cmis:document WHERE cmis:objectTypeId IN ('bb:image', 'bb:richtext','bb:link')

    LIKE

    Matches the value against a specified pattern. Use a percent % and underscore _ to form patterns. The percent character represents zero or more of characters. The underscore character represents one character.

    For example, the following statement returns all documents with a name starting with j:

    SELECT * FROM cmis:document WHERE cmis:name LIKE 'j%'

    This statement returns all XML files with a four-letter name starting with j:

    SELECT * FROM cmis:document WHERE cmis:name LIKE 'j___.xml'

    Use the keywords OR and AND to combine conditional statements. AND takes precedence over OR.

  • ORDER BY

    The ORDER BY clause is optional and sorts the result list. Use ascending (ASC) or descending (DESC) order. The default order is ascending.

    For example, the following query returns all XML documents and orders them ascending by object ID:

    SELECT * FROM cmis:document WHERE cmis:contentStreamMimeType = 'text/xml' ORDER BY cmis:objectId

    This query returns the same rows, but in descending order:

    SELECT * FROM cmis:document WHERE cmis:contentStreamMimeType = 'text/xml' ORDER BY cmis:objectId DESC

Top

3.2 Paging, Filtering and Sorting

Content Services implements parts of the CMIS 1.0 Common Service Elements to navigate repositories through HTTP requests. In particular the paging, filtering and sorting URL modifiers trim down large HTTP responses and make them more manageable.

Filtering Properties

The filter URL modifier determines the properties included in the HTTP response. The response will always contain the required properties cmis:name, cmis:objectTypeId and cmis:baseTypeId, regardless of the filter modifier.

For example, the following request returns the required properties and the cmis:objectId property for the children of the object with the specified ID:

GET http://host/path/contentRepository/children?id=2eeb962f-0187-4cf0-aa2b-2e131c36612b&filter=cmis:objectId

You can add multiple properties separated by a comma:

GET http://host/path/contentRepository/children?id=2eeb962f-0187-4cf0-aa2b-2e131c36612b&filter=cmis:objectId,cmis:path
Remove Allowable Actions

The response includes a list of actions allowed on the returned objects. To prevent the inclusion of these allowable actions, set the includeAllowableActions modifier to false, as follows: 

GET http://host/path/contentRepository/children?id=2eeb962f-0187-4cf0-aa2b-2e131c36612b&filter=cmis:objectId&includeAllowableActions=false
Paging

Use the paging modifiers to distribute the responses on multiple pages:

Table 3.2. Paging Modifiers

Modifier

Description

maxItems

Page size: the number of results in the response.

skipCount

Page number: the first result number in the response.


For example, the following request returns the first twelve results (the first page with twelve items):

GET http://host/path/contentRepository/children?id=92cf712b-043f-4e5b-a605-e1ca3834b4fb&maxItems=12&skipCount=0

The following request returns the third page with twelve items:

GET http://host/path/contentRepository/children?id=92cf712b-043f-4e5b-a605-e1ca3834b4fb&maxItems=12&skipCount=24
Sorting

Use the orderBy modifier to sort the results ascending (ASC) or descending (DESC). Place a space encoded as %20 between the property and the ASC or DESC value. The following example sorts the results ascending by the cmis:name property, and descending by the cmis:path property:

GET http://host/path/contentRepository/children?id=92cf712b-043f-4e5b-a605-e1ca3834b4fb&maxItems=12&skipCount=0&orderBy=cmis:name%20ASC,cmis:path%20DESC

4 Integration with Backbase Portal

4.1. Repository Objects
4.2. Feeds
4.3. Remote CMIS Content

You can integrate Content Services repository content directly in a Widget Definition, a Containers or a Page Template. Using importers such as RSS and Atom feed importers or CMIS importers, however, requires some initial configuration steps.

This chapter explains how to insert repository objects in page templates and widgets, how to create widgets that display RSS feeds, Atom feeds, or CMIS importers.

4.1 Repository Objects

You can integrate repository content objects directly in a Widget Definition, a Containers or a Page Template as long as the object ID and URL are correct.

It is of course possible to integrate repository objects into widgets by using Backbase Portal Manager. See Architecture for more information.

The following section shows how to use repository images in page templates and widgets.

  1. Upload content

    Prepare an image you would like to use for this example. For instance, you can use the top banner of the Backbase documentation web-site with URL http://docs.backbase.com/common/images/logo_docs.png, but of course any image will do.

    Access the contentRepository repository and upload the image as a bb:image object.

    If you are using CMIS Workbench, see CMIS Workbench.

  2. Retrieve the object ID

    Note down the value of the cmis:objectId property or copy it to the clipboard from a CMIS client like CMIS Workbench.

    Note

    Replace the object URL and ID in the examples below.

  3. Modify page templates

    You can handle repository objects like common objects in HTML declarations, JSP files or CSS stylesheets as long as the URL is complete and contains the object ID. For example, the following is a valid element: 

    <img src="http://localhost:8080/contentservices/atom/contentRepository/content/backbaselogo.png?id=b15b33fd-6ad3-4ef4-9e2b-10b675fa6844" />

    You can modify the Page Template to make it display a header with the logout link by adding the following <div> element: 

    <div id="header" style="height:100px;
    background-image:url(http://localhost:port/contentservices/atom/contentRepository/content/image_filename?id=object_id)">

    <sec:authorize ifNotGranted="role_anonymous"><a
     href="<c:url value="/j_spring_security_logout"/>">logout</a></sec:authorize>
    <sec:authentication property="name"/>

</div>

    The lines above set the image as background of the <div> element and display the user name and logout link.

  4. Modify widget definitions

    You can modify widget definitions in a similar way. For example, replace the widget definition from the Portal Example with the following: 

    <!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN"
 "http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd">
<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xml:lang="en">
    <head>
        <meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8"/>
        <title>Hello World</title>
    </head>
    <body>
        <p>Hello World of Content Services</p>
        <img src="http://localhost:port/contentservices/atom/contentRepository/content/image_filename?id=object_id" />
    </body>
</html>

    The code above displays the repository image within the widget.

  5. Import files

    Import the page template and the widget definition as explained in How to Implement a Custom Page Template. You can now point a browser to the portal URI and verify that it displays the image.

Top

4.2 Feeds

Content Services imports RSS and Atom feeds from remote CMIS repositories through feed Importers. It stores the feeds in contentRepository from where you can use them within a Widget Definition, Containers or a Page Template.

The following procedure explains how to import an Atom feed:

  1. Create configurationRepository folders

    Access configurationRepository through the Atom REST interface or CMIS Workbench and create a folder named importers and a subfolder named feed. Create one more folder named scheduler in the repository root and a subfolder named jobs. For more information, see the Enabling WebDAV.

  2. Create a feed importer configuration

    Create an importer configuration file with the content below, save it with a .properties extension on the file system and upload it to the importers/feed folder you created in the step above. Make sure the new object is of cmis:document type: 

    id=importer_id
group=feedgroup
description=any_description
targetRepositoryId=contentRepository
targetFolderPath=target_folder
remoteLocation=feed_address
defaultEncoding=utf-8

    If for example you want to import the Bloomberg Blog feed, fill out the configuration file as follows:

    id=BloombergBlog
group=feedgroup
description=The Bloomberg Blog Feed
targetRepositoryId=contentRepository
targetFolderPath=/myfeeds
remoteLocation=http://inside.bloomberg.com/blog/atom.xml
defaultEncoding=utf-8

    Save it as BloombergBlog.properties. The lines above create a feed importer called BloombergBlog that belongs to feedgroup, receives the feed from http://inside.bloomberg.com/blog/atom.xml, stores the imported content in the myfeeds folder within contentRepository, and uses UTF-8 encoding.

    For more information, see Importers.

    Note

    All importer configurations must have a .properties extension.

  3. Enable importer jobs

    Content Services automatically runs Importer Jobs according to a given schedule. However, importer jobs are disabled by default: to enable them, open the contentservices.properties file located in your application server lib folder, add the following line and save the file: 

    repository.scheduler.enabled=true

  4. Create an importer job configuration

    Create a file named job1feedgroup.properties with the content below, save it on the file system and upload it to the scheduler/job folder in configurationRepository making sure the new object is of cmis:document type:

    #this job runs the feedgroup importer configurations every 20 seconds
id=myJob1
jobGroup=feedgroup
cron=0/20 * * * * ?

    The lines above create a scheduler job named myJob1 that runs the feedgroup importers (such as BloombergBlog defined above) every twenty seconds. For more information, please refer to Quartz 1.x Tutorials: crontrigger.

    Note

    All importer job configurations must have a .properties extension.

  5. Create target folder

    Access contentRepository and create a folder where Content Services can store the imported content. For the Bloomberg Blog example above, name the folder myfeeds.

  6. Restart Content Services

    Restart Content Services to make the changes effective. The target folder in contenRepository (e.g. myfeeds) should contain an XML file with the feed.

You can apply CSS styles to the XML feeds or transform them to HTML with XSLT and display their content within widgets. For more information, see the page on the integration of Repository Objects.

Top

4.3 Remote CMIS Content

CMIS importers fetch content from remote CMIS repositories and import it into contentRepository in Content Services. For more information, see Importers.

The following procedure shows how to configure an importer and schedule its execution.

  1. Create configurationRepository folders

    Access configurationRepository and create two folders named, respectively, /importers/cmis and /scheduler/jobs.

  2. Create a CMIS importer configuration

    Create an importer configuration file with the content below, save it with a .properties extension on the file system and upload it to the importers/cmis folder you created in the step above. Make sure the new object is of cmis:document type: 

    id=importer_id
group=cmisgroup
description=some_description

sourceCmisLocation=source_repository_address
sourceCmisRepositoryId=source_repository_id
sourceCmisFolderPath=source_repository_folder
sourceUserName=username
sourcePassword=username

targetCmisLocation=target_repository_address
targetCmisRepositoryId=target_repository_id
targetCmisFolderPath=/target_repository_folder
targetUserName=username
targetPassword=password

defaultEncoding=utf-8

    For example, the following configuration imports content from /TestFolder in the Alfresco 3.4 CMIS Content Repository into the Alfresco folder in contentRepository:

    id=AlfrescoCmisImporter
group=cmisgroup
description=This Importer Fetches Content from the Alfresco 4.x Public Repository

sourceCmisLocation=http://cmis.alfresco.com/service/cmis
sourceCmisRepositoryId=371554cd-ac06-40ba-98b8-e6b60275cca7
sourceCmisFolderPath=/TestFolder
sourceUserName=admin
sourcePassword=admin

targetCmisLocation=http://host:port/contentservices/atom
targetCmisRepositoryId=contentRepository
targetCmisFolderPath=/Alfresco
targetUserName=admin
targetPassword=admin

defaultEncoding=utf-8

    For more information, see Importers.

    Note

    All importer configurations must have a .properties extension.

  3. Enable importer jobs

    Importer jobs are disabled by default. To enable them, open the contentservices.properties file located in your application server lib folder, add the following line, and save the file: 

    repository.scheduler.enabled=true

  4. Create an importer job configuration

    Create a file named job2cmisgroup.properties, fill it with the lines below, and upload it to the /scheduler/job folder in configurationRepository as a cmis:document object:

    #this job runs the cmisgroup importer configurations every 5 minutes
id=myJob2
jobGroup=cmisgroup
cron=* 0/5 * * * ?

    The myJob2 scheduler runs the importers in the cmisgroup (like the AlfrescoCmisImporter defined above) every five minutes. For more information, please refer to Quartz 1.x Tutorials: crontrigger.

    Note

    All importer job configurations must have a .properties extension.

  5. Create target folder

    Access contentRepository and create a folder where Content Services can store the imported content. For the Alfresco example above, name the folder /Alfresco.

  6. Restart Content Services

    Restart Content Services to make the changes effective.

    The target folder in contenRepository repository (e.g. Alfresco) should fill up with the content from the Guest Home folder in the Alfresco repository.

5 Renditions

5.1. Rendition Engines
5.2. Rendition Services
5.3. Thumbnail Rendition Engine
5.4. Custom Renditions

Content Services repositories can provide alternative representations, or renditions, of the same document: for example the thumbnail preview of an image, the PDF version of a text document, or the XSLT transformation of an XML file. The creation of renditions is managed by rendition services that invoke a rendition engine, i.e. the piece of software actually carrying out the transformation.

The figure below is a sequence diagram showing the cycle of rendition creation:

Content Services creates and modifies renditions whenever a CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete) event occurs in the repository: the CRUD event triggers a rendition service that invokes the relevant rendition engine. The engine then carries out the transformations necessary to create the rendition and returns the transformed document to the repository.

Content Services currently only ships with a Thumbnail Rendition Engine, but more Custom Renditions can be added.

For more information, please refer to the CMIS Standard released by the OASIS consortium.

5.1 Rendition Engines

Rendition engines carry out the transformations needed to create specific rendition types. Every rendition requires a different engine: for example, creating thumbnails requires a different engine than converting text documents to PDFs.

A rendition engine extends the RenditionEngine abstract class. RenditionEngine class has two main abstract methods, createRenditions and updateRenditions, and some helper methods.

createRenditions and updateRenditions return a list of one or more rendition objects of the RenditionData type as detailed in the OpenCMIS specification.

The renditionData type has the following properties, named rendition attributes in the OpenCMIS specification:

Table 5.1. Rendition Attributes

Property

Mandatory

Description

streamId

✓

The stream unique identifier.

mimeType

✓

The MIME type of the rendition stream.

length

-

The length of the rendition stream in bytes.

title

-

Human readable information about the rendition.

kind

✓

A categorization string associated with the rendition.

height

-

Typically used for 'image' renditions (expressed as pixels). SHOULD be present if kind = cmis:thumbnail.

width

-

Typically used for 'image' renditions (expressed as pixels). SHOULD be present if kind = cmis:thumbnail.

renditionDocumentId

-

If specified, then the rendition can also be accessed as a document object in the CMIS services. If not set, then the rendition can only be accessed via the rendition services. Referential integrity of this ID is repository-specific.


For more information, please refer to the CMIS Standard released by the OASIS consortium.

For more information, please refer to the MIME media types released by IANA.

Top

5.2 Rendition Services

Rendition services are triggered whenever a CRUD event occurs in the repository. Rendition services are implementations of the RenditionService abstract class. The RenditionService class contains these methods described in detail below: executeCreate, executeUpdate, executeDelete, and executeMove.

5.3 Thumbnail Rendition Engine

Content Services ships with the thumbnail rendition engine that creates thumbnail renditions of repository objects. The thumbnail rendition engine can, for instance, create a 100x100 pixels thumbnail of an image or assign a default thumbnail image to a repository folder.

The rendition engine will preserve the proportions when scaling an image:

The thumbnail size, the default directory for the thumbnails and the default thumbnail image are specified in the bb-contentservices-repository-rendition.xml, as shown below. 

<bean name="thumbnailRenditionEngine"
      class="com.backbase.portal.contentservices.rendition.engine.impl.ThumbnailRenditionEngine">
    <constructor-arg value=".renditions"/>
    <property name="folderImg" value="images/folderImg.jpeg"/>
</bean>
<bean name="thumbnailRenditionService100"
      class="com.backbase.portal.contentservices.rendition.service.impl.ThumbnailRenditionService">
    <constructor-arg ref="thumbnailRenditionEngine"/>
    <property name="formats">
        <list>
            <value>100</value>
        </list>
    </property>
    <property name="enabled" value="true"/>
</bean>

<bean name="renditionServiceManager"
      class="com.backbase.portal.contentservices.rendition.RenditionServiceManager">
    <constructor-arg>
        <list>
            <ref bean="thumbnailRenditionService100"/>
        </list>
    </constructor-arg>
</bean>

Set the path of the renditions folder. The path is relative to the object location in the repository. For instance, if the example.jpg file resides in the images folder, the engine specified above will store the thumbnail rendition in the images/.renditions folder.

Set the image of the folder.

Set the thumbnail size in pixels.

Top

5.4 Custom Renditions

Content Services makes it possible to create custom renditions. In order to do so, follow these steps:

  1. Create a new engine class by extending the RenditionEngine abstract class and save it under WEB-INF/lib in the Content Services folder.

  2. Register a Spring bean for the new engine

    1. Unpack the contentservices-webapp-5.2.1.0.war file.

    2. Edit the bb-contentservices-repository-rendition.xml file.

    3. Register the Spring bean for the new engine as follows:

      <bean name="engine_name"
      class="engine_class_name">
    <constructor-arg value="default_rendition_folder"/>
</bean>

  3. Create a new service class extending the RenditionService abstract class. The RenditionService class contains methods that are invoked after a CRUD event in Content Services repositories.

  4. Register a Spring bean for the new service and wire it up with the engine

    1. Edit the bb-contentservices-repository-rendition.xml file.

    2. Register the Spring bean for the new service as follows:

      <bean name="service_name"
      class="class_name">
    <constructor-arg ref="engine_name"/>

    <!-- list here optional properties -->

    <property name="enabled" value="true"/>
</bean>

  5. List the service bean in the renditionServiceManager bean

    1. Edit the bb-contentservices-repository-rendition.xml file.

    2. Add the service to the renditionServiceManager bean:

      <bean name="renditionServiceManager"
 class="com.backbase.portal.contentservices.rendition.RenditionServiceManager">
    <constructor-arg>
        <list>
            <ref bean="service_name"/>
        </list>
    </constructor-arg>
</bean>

  6. Repack the contentservices-webapp-5.2.1.0.war file and restart Content Services.

6 Validators

6.1. Custom Validators

Content Services can validate CRUD operations before executing them. For example, it can cancel the creation of an object if the required properties are not set.

Rules about CRUD operations in the repository are defined and enforced by validators:

A listener mechanism intercepts all CRUD events in the repository and calls a validator engine. The validator engine then calls all the registered validators: if an operation does not comply to a rule, the validator throws an exception and the operation is canceled. Otherwise, the validator engine returns control to the listener and to the repository service that carries out the requested operation.

Content Services currently ships with only the RepositorySchemaValidator validator, but one can create Custom Validators.

The RepositorySchemaValidator validator checks that an object complies to its type schema before a create/update operation. In other words, it ensures that all required properties are set and keeps all repository objects in valid state.

6.1 Custom Validators

Content Services makes it possible to easily create custom validators. In order to do so, follow these steps:

  1. Create a validator class that implements the RepositoryValidator interface and save it under WEB-INF/lib in the Content Services folder. For more information, please refer to the Content Services Javadoc API.

  2. Register the validator in the contentservices.properties file. This file is located on the classpath, e.g. in the lib folder of the application server, or create the file if it doesn't exist yet. Validators are registered under the validators key. Multiple validators should be comma-separated as shown below:

    validators=com.backbase.portal.contentservices.validator.impl.RepositorySchemaValidator,
com.yourcompany.contentservices.validator.impl.YourOwnValidator

    Note

    The validator engine calls validators in the same order they appear in the configuration file. In other words, order matters.

  3. Restart the appication server.

Top

7 Third-Party Tools

7.1. CMIS Workbench
7.2. Mounting Repositories

A number of tools are available to access and manipulate CMIS repositories. This chapter includes some simple explanations about using CMIS Workbench, BitKinex, and mapping repositories to network drives in Microsoft Windows or mounting them on a Linux file system. Please refer to the web-sites of those programs and operating systems for more detailed documentation.

7.1 CMIS Workbench

CMIS Workbench is a popular CMIS desktop client you can use to access Content Services repositories. This section shows how to use CMIS Workbench to carry out some common activities. Similar applications you can use are CMIS Explorer and OpenCMIS Browser.

Accessing Repositories

After launching CMIS Workbench a login pop-up window appears. Enter the Atom address in the URL field of the in the Basic tab. The address syntax is http://host:port/applicationcontext/atom:

Table 7.1. Content Services URL Parts

URL Part

Default

Description

The host name of the server that hosts Content Services.

Apache Tomcat: 8080

WebSphere: 9080

JBoss: 8080

You can set the port in the application server settings.

applicationcontext

contentservices

This value usually reflects the name of the deployed WAR file.


The default username and password are, respectively, admin and admin.

Select the AtomPub binding, then click on Load Repositories, pick a repository and click on Login:

Uploading Content

Warning

Due to compatibility issues, CMIS Workbench cannot upload content items of the custom types bb:link and bb:image.

You cannot create documents directly in the repository: you need to upload existing files from the local file system. Click Create Document, select a file from the file system and select Document Type (cmis:document). Click Create Document in the pop-up window when you are done. For more information, see CMIS Object Model.

Warning

Don't select any of the bb: object types, but only cmis:document. The bb: object types are custom types of Content Services. Using these object types in CMIS Workbench will result in corrupt files.

Retrieving Object IDs

If you want to embed repository objects into Backbase Portal you need to know the correct URL and object ID. Access the corresponding repository, navigate its structure in the left pane and select the relevant object. Note down the Content URL displayed on the right-hand pane under the Object tab, or right-click on the URL to copy it to the clipboard:

7.2 Mounting Repositories

Both Microsoft Windows and the offer the possibility of accessing a repository as if it where part of the local file system. This page explains how to map a network drive under Microsoft Windows and how to mount a repository to a Unix file system.

Mapping a Network Drive under Microsoft Windows

Microsoft Windows provides a WebDAV client called WebDAV Mini Redirector. Follow these steps to map a network drive to a repository:

  1. Right-click on My Computer and select Map Network Drive....

1 Overview

Content Services is a content delivery platform provided as a Backbase Portal optional module. It provides repository capabilities and relies on a library of Importers to harvest content from sources like CMIS repositories or RSS and Atom feeds.

The following figure shows the elements composing Content Services:

Repositories

Content Services implements the CMIS Standard and relies on three repositories to manage content and configuration files:

  • contentRepository stores content used by Backbase Portal, like images, text, and content harvested from remote sources. One can navigate this repository from the Content Browser in Backbase Portal Manager. For more information, see Architecture.

  • configurationRepository stores configuration files for Importers.

  • resourcesRepository stores Backbase Portal resources.

Interfaces

Content Services is accessible via the following interfaces:

  • CMIS interface: enables interaction with any of the three repositories (contentRepository, configurationRepository, and resourcesRepository) at a very low level, for example down to metadata. You can establish connections using a CMIS client such as CMIS Workbench, via Paging, Filtering and Sorting URL modifiers, or by implementing a Mashup Services custom data provider.

  • WebDAV interface: allows to manipulate objects and folders in Content Services repositories. WebDAV clients such as BitKinex and WebDAV-enabled applications such as Adobe Dreamweaver CS5 provide both file system and editing support. For file system operations alone, a WebDAV-enabled file manager like Microsoft Windows Explorer is sufficient. For more information, see Mounting Repositories.

  • JMX interface: manages and monitors the content delivery service and is useful to configure and administer the Content Services server. For more information, see JMX Interface.

1 Overview

Mashup Services is an embedded module delivering remote content to Backbase Portal widgets. It acts as a proxy and allows to cache, filter and transform HTTP requests and responses.

The following figure shows the workflow of requests and responses through Mashup Services:

The Mashup Services proxying, transformation, and caching features are tailored specifically for delivering content to Backbase Portal widgets, as follows:

  • Proxy

    The proxy service is responsible for retrieving content from a remote data source. For security reasons, Backbase Portal cannot directly include remote data sources. The proxy service is an intermediary between Backbase Portal and the remote server.

    For more information on this security requirement, see en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Same_origin_policy.

  • Transform

    The transform service filters and/or transforms external data. Mashup Services is delivered with a library of predefined filters, transformers, and data-providers. For more information, see Pre-defined Elements.

  • Cache

    The cache service improves performance by storing remote server responses in a cache. This prevents unnecessarily frequent requests and responses. The cache service relies on Ehcache.
